subject: Project 2 FAQ
content: Refer to this post for Frequently Asked Questions regarding Project 2. Project 2 is due Friday, February 3 at 8pm.  Please keep the followups related to questions in this post only.. Spec is here. .  . Resize GUI repository (you can use this to easily try your resize code on other images!): https://github.com/oalejel/resize-GUI.  . Write clear code! This is especially important for this project, remember:. Matrix width = # of columns. Matrix height = # of rows. Instead of using variables like "i" and "j" in your for-loops, consider using "row" and "col" so you don't get confused!. . Main Project Files Questions (Matrix.h, Image.h, processing.cpp, resize.cpp). . Q: When should I use the -> operator? . A: For Matrix, use the -> operator when you are implementing functions only in the Matrix.h file. Good coding style keeps the direct access to matrix objects using the -> operator to a specific set of functions. We actually consider this incorrect behavior, even if you get the right results, so please make sure you use the right function. The same goes for Image and Pixel. . . Q: Why do I have to write functions like Matrix_width? Couldn't I just use matrix->width directly?. A: As explained in the previous question, you should only use the -> operator to directly access a type of struct in a specific set of functions. In Image.h functions and resize.cpp, if you want to access the width of a matrix, you can’t use the -> operator, so we need a function.. . Q: Am I required to use traversal by pointer?. A: No. You are allowed to, but not required to use traversal by pointer in this project. You should choose to traverse by index/pointer based on what makes sense to you logically..  . Q: My program takes a couple minutes or more to run. Is this expected?. A: Yes, but not too long - your program should run in under 30 seconds. Double check that you're not looping unnecessarily or calling an inefficient function within a loop. Perf is also a helpful tool for improving efficiency! https://eecs280staff.github.io/p2-cv/#appendix-b-perf-tutorial.  . Q: Rotate left is failing, even though it was provided. Is there an error in the provided function?. A: Rotate left calls several student implemented image functions, which can cause errors in rotate left.. . Q: Why do we need to create a copy of the image in remove_vertical_seam? How can we do it?. A: When removing a vertical seam, the image has to be smaller. Images are array’s, which have a fixed size, so we have to create a new image that is smaller. We can then copy the pixels over one by one, removing the desired pixels as you go. Since we are passing in an Image pointer, we are passing an address to an Image object. We can then change the pointer to point to the new image object created. Write out a memory diagram to help visualize how this works!.  . Testing Questions. . Q: How can I test Matrix_at without breaking the interface?. A: When thinking of unit testing, you should think in units as behavior instead of units as functions, because it is common to have functions like Matrix_at that solely rely on the underlying implementation. When testing Matrix_at, we really want to test the behavior of setting and retrieving independent values reliably from our matrix. For example, you could test that setting a value at (0,1) doesn't modify the value at (1,0) or other similar variations of this.. . Q: Why am I failing crabster but passing dog and horses?. A: Crabster tends to catch more edge cases. Be sure that in all cases you're checking the correct columns when you compute the energy, cost, and seam.. . Q: One of my processing test is failing, but when I print out the output it matches the correct file.. A: Double check your image init. If you read in the correct image incorrectly, then Image_equal will fail even if you've processed the image correctly.. . Q: I am missing some test cases. What other tests should I write to catch the test cases?. A: Sorry! We don't share what test cases the AG is looking for. The best advice we can give it to brainstorm more edge cases. . . Q: When will project grades be released?. A: You will be able to see your score including the private tests on the autograder approximately a week after the project deadline.. . Setup Questions. . Q: I'm trying to run processing_public_test.cpp/resize.cpp on XCode, and Xcode is saying that it's unable to open dog.ppm/crabster.ppm/horses.ppm.. A: You need to update XCode's custom working directory: https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/setup_xcode.html#run.  . Happy coding!

subject: p2 autograder final grade
content: Hello, I was checking my autograder final score today and realized that the autograder only chose to grade my second to last submission. My last submission included bug fixes that I believe would have fixed some of the areas where we lost points. I was wondering where in particular the autograder marked us down in the final submission and why it would have resulted in a lower grade than the second to last. my um-id is 48817232
i_answer: The autograder automatically selects the submission that would give you the highest score.

subject: Do we also need to write the implementatoin for the friend function ?

I then tried cancelling the submission but the page started to not respond so I closed it. So I submitted it again after so I was wondering if this submission would not count.
i_answer: As long as you started the submission before the deadline, it will still count

subject: Resize UB check fail
content: So I passed the public test for resize.cpp, but failed the UB check during run time due to a supposed memory leak. My AG score was 62/64 due to missing a bug per test suite.. . How bad will the resize UB check fail come back to bite me when the private tests are ran?
i_answer: Unfortunately it's hard to say, given the nature of undefined behavior. In the future we recommend setting up the address sanitizer to avoid issues like this: https://eecs280staff.github.io/tutorials/setup_asan.html

subject: Style best score
content: Hi,. . I was just wondering how the style grading works. I heard that the best score is taken from autograder, does it take the corresponding style grade from the best score too? My last submission lost three points from long functions therefore giving me 61/64, but I had a 64/64 earlier. Will it grade my code for the 64/64 one? . . Thank you
i_answer: The score that you will get will be the best total score, combined public and private, that you got from any single submission. The style checks are part of this.

subject: autograder latest submission
content: Hi,. . My last submission for the autograder was yesterday. Will it use that submission for the final score?
i_answer: Your final graded score will be according to whichever of your submissions scored the highest (including private test cases).

subject: Late Days for Projects ?
content: My score for project 2 was low because I didn’t close a few brackets before submitting it to the queue even though my code didn’t match the grade it got. Is there a way I can appeal for a late day or something similar ?
i_answer: There are no late days for projects. Late days are usually only granted for extenuating circumstances. If you think this applies to you, then fill out the Extension form.

subject: autograder submission
content: I just used my final submission to autograder and everything works as intended except I get a UB check on resize.cpp because, on the pathway where the file prints all the way, I returned 1 (like in the error cases) when 0 was expected. I still got 1/1 for the public case, however. Will this affect my grade on the private tests and, if so, could I use an extra submission to change this since there is nothing in the spec about which return value to use for the successful case?
i_answer: For the sake of fairness, we do not allow extra submissions on a case-by-case basis except in extenuating personal circumstances.

subject: Does the queue delay our submission time?
content: Hi,. . Is our submission marked as when it made it out of the queue or when we hit submit? What if our queue goes after the deadline?. . Thanks
i_answer: It's marked when we hit submit.

I've tried parsing through but it is difficult to find where in processing this could be referring to, could I get some help with this?.
i_answer: Run your code with a debugger and see the call stack where the assertion fails. See where Matrix_at gets called, and your issue is probably there. You are trying to call Matrix_at with an invalid column.

On autograder's Resize Public Test, we get an X for Run (no output), but the check is correct and shows our output is the same. subject: Error for image tests
content: We got this error on autograder. Does anyone know what this means?.
i_answer: The error is a memory leak. In other words, you are forgetting to delete a matrix/image that you created with the "new" keyword earlier in your function. To fix the error, make sure you type "delete mat;" or whatever similar phrase depending on your variable name. Every time you create a new image/matrix you should make sure to delete in at the end of the function. . .

subject: Long Functions in main
content: My main function in resize has too many lines. If I break it into functions, will the lines in the function definitions also be counted by the style test, or do only lines inside the main function count?
i_answer: Lines are counted by whatever is in the function, not by any lines within any called functions. Breaking into functions sounds like a good move.

subject: crabster seam_carve 70x35 function
content: Hello, we were able to figure out that our code works for all test cases except crabster 70x35 seam carve. I also suggest you utilize Matrix_at() in your Matrix functions instead of directly accessing mat->data.

subject: Assertion Confusion
content: I am confused as to whether we have to assert the following requirements since I think it is hard to make assertions.. 1. mat points to a Matrix. 2. img points to a Image. 3. mat points to a valid Matrix. 4. img points to a valid Image. 5. the size of seam is == Image_height(img). 6. the size of seam is >= Matrix_height(cost). 7. each element x in seam satisfies 0 <= x < Image_width(img). Do we have to assert the above requirements in RME to gain a higher score? If so, how can I assert those? I think these requirements are hard to be directly tested by using assert statements.
i_answer: RME assertion statements are not graded. asserting the RME can be helpful for debugging purposes, though -- it can help you know if the values being passed into a function are wrong or the function itself.

subject: 9/10 Matrix tests
content: We need some help for matrix_tests.cpp in trying to find the last bug. I've tried all the suggestions on Piazza and I tried the suggestions given during OH but I'm not sure what is missing (or if I'm writing them wrongly).. . Any help is appreciated! Thank you. . . My uniqname is izareese.
i_answer: Your current test suite looks strong. I'm afraid I don't have any insight into the bugs you're missing, but I would revisit some of your smaller tests, and think about other types of "interesting" matrices you can try with them. For example, for tests that involve looping over the Matrix, make sure you're testing every meaningful type of Matrix shape (for example, I classify them as single-element (i.e. height and width are 1), square (height == width), and rectangular (height != width). And for testing functions that check the integer values in the Matrix, consider how you can create Matrices with "interesting" values; for example, how does Matrix_max() behave with a Matrix with all the same numbers? All negative? Mix of positive/negative?. . Thinking through these edge cases will better inform your test-writing.

subject: ./resize.exe output
content: when I ran the resize.cpp by using ./resize.exe horses.ppm horses_400x250.ppm 400 250. The terminal showed. "resize.exe(60134,0x1157f5600) malloc: nano zone abandoned due to inability to preallocate reserved vm space." I am confused as whether this is the normal output. But I discovered I can make the correct resize ppm, and the autograder showed full points for my code. So do I need to fix this problem?. .
i_answer: See @10 for an explanation of this message. In short, it just means an optimization macOS tries to perform at the start of your program failed; this won't affect the correctness of your program. As long as your code works on the autograder, that's all we care about. To learn more about this message (and how to get rid of it), check out this Stack Overflow post.

subject: Resize public test and unbounded error
content: I'm having an issue with the dog.ppm file not opening and some leak sanitizer errors in auto grader. Im not sure if they're related or not and I read some other posts but still couldn't figure it out. Would someone be able to check for me? my uniqname is manvithm..
i_answer: The leak occurred because you created a new Image object in your main function, but when you couldn't open dog.ppm, your program exited without deleting the Image object. This is acceptable behavior; you don't need to handle this "leak," since all of your program's memory will be reclaimed by the operating system automatically when your program terminates, rendering the leak benign.. . The problem seems to be your output file is the same as your input file. These should be different filenames, right? Double-check your main function for this.

subject: find_minimal_vertical_seam
content: I don't know why I can't change the values in seam. I tried to use debugger and it seems that Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row returns the correct column number. But both seam[cost->height - 1] = endpt and seam[row] = col_min don't change my seam array. .
i_answer: Remember that arrays decay into pointers when passed into a function, so *seam is showing you the value of seam[0] (which probably hasn't been set by your loop yet, in the screenshot). To see all of seam's values, go up one function in the call stack, and you should be able to expand seam in the variables panel to see its elements.

subject: processing.cpp energy and cost matrix edge cases
content: Should we implement code that accounts for a 2x2 or lower-sized image that will calculate the energy/cost matrices correctly?.
i_answer: Check the RME for each function. For example, the RME for remove_vertical_seam says "// REQUIRES: img points to a valid Image with width >= 2 ". This means you wouldn't have to handle the case where width is <2 in that function. You should always consider what happens when you're doing the calculation on a border column, and this applies to the 2x2 case as well.

subject: Using test_helper functions
content: Does "respecting the interface" include using the test helper functions in our unit tests? Would we be fine if we didn't use them?
i_answer: Yes. You need to respect the interface in your test functions. Using helper functions doesn't qualify as breaking the interface though. Breaking the interface would be accessing private member variables in your tests (e.g. mat->data in matrix_tests.cpp). You do not have to use helper functions in test cases but they are helpful

subject: UNKNOWN - processing_public_tests passing on terminal but not AG
content: When I run the public processing tests on my terminal, every test case passes, but when I submit if on the autograder, none of the cases (dog, horse, crabster) pass. . . . . I have already tried:. 1. Checking memory leaks for dynamic memory. 2. Running the code on CAEN - but when I tried to make resize.exe, there is an error so I think there's something with my CAEN setup. .  . . . This is what happens when I try to make resize.exe using CAEN.
i_answer: The strategies you tried are very smart! Whenever something works locally but not on the autograder check for undefined behavior.. . I did look at your code and saw what might be causing the issue. Remember that the Matrix_min_value_in_row ending bound is exclusive! That means it won't analyze the column_end index given. For example if you wanted to search the first two columns in a row (aka columns 0 and 1). You would have to pass in column_start = 0 and column_end = 2. Make sure that any time you call the matrix_min_value_in_row you keep the exclusivity in mind.. . Hope this helps! Thank you for following the requested format!

subject: can we use fstream::rdbuf() for Image_tests.cpp?
content: If I want to convert a ppm file into an istream to test Image_init, here's my current plan:. . subject: Creating test cases
content: I just want to clarify something. So when I'm making test cases, am I allowed to put multiple ones under the same TEST(function_name) test or do I have to make a new TEST(function_name) for different tests of the same function? To clarify, let's say I am testing two different test cases for Matrix fill. Can I have:. . TEST(matrix_fill){.  test case 1. . test case 2. }. . or would I have to write it as:. . TEST(matrix_fill_1){}. . TEST(matrix_fill_2){}
i_answer: You are allowed to test multiple things and have multiple asserts within  your test. However, it would make sense of each of your "sub-tests" within your test functions are logically similar.

subject: How does the autograder grade the best submission?

For example, if 1 submission had a perfect resize.cpp but didn't pass mutation testing, and a 2nd submission had perfect mutation testing, but somehow didn't pass resize. Would we receive a perfect score since there were cases of both being perfect, or is it just the higher of the 2 overall submissions?
i_answer: It will take the higher of the 2 overall submissions.

subject: Processing functions are working for dog, but not crab or horse
content: For the processing public tests, the code is able to pass the dog tests but fails at the crab cost matrix. However, the code still compiled, so I looked over it to write resize.cpp and after using a ppm to image converter it seemed like all the processing was fine and that the images were the same. I also cross checked that the bottom rows of both the correct cost matrix and the one I got and they were the exact same, which doesn't make sense since if they were different the chance that every number lining up on the bottom would be extremely low. As such, I'm curious as to why this could be happening?. .
i_answer: Great question! Typically what would be different is the size of the image. Dog is a square and crab and horse get more rectangular. If you mixed up your rows and columns somewhere, it may not be that impactful in a small square but would make a huge difference in a rectangle (you may even go out of bounds).. . Another key difference that comes into play more in the remove vertical seam is the seam remove is different for each image. One image may remove only middle pixels while one image may remove some from both edges and middle.

subject: remove matrix seam
content: Good evening,. . I am having quite a bit of trouble with my remove matrix seam function. I have spent north of 4 hours trying to debug and even fully rewrite my program, but it is still failing.. . Below are my 2 implementations. Neither work. .
i_answer: In your first screenshot you are very close to the correct answer! You only need the first for loop and the two nested ones. I love the very first nested for loop. It catches all the cases where the column is less than the removed column. The second nested for loop has the correct condition...it handles all the columns that are greater than the removed seam. The only bug is, you get the pixel from (r,c) and set it in our new image at (r,c). Since you are removing a pixel, you are getting rid of a column so it will be offset by one. Try setting the pixel in the new image at (r, c-1).

subject: Assert errors
content: A lot of my assertions are failing, which is definitely not good and I'm not sure how to fix this. Ive tried tracing through but I haven't been able to find anything wrong. Is there any way I van get help with this?.
i_answer: Assertion error means that your implementation breaks the requirement of the functions. For example, seam_carve() requires "0 < newWidth <= Image_width(img)", but if the newWidth you passed into the function is bigger than original width, you would have assertion error. The next step is to check outside this function, and think why and at which step you happen to pass in a wrong newWidth. For example, if you accidentally switched the newHeight and newWidth before/when you call this function, this requirement might be broken.. You may want to apply similar strategies to all the assertions that you failed, and update your code accordingly.

subject: Processing tests
content: I am pretty much done with project 2 and I feel very confident in my implementations of Image.cpp and Matrix.cpp. My processing.cpp also passes all public tests, but I am still feeling a bit worried about the private tests for processing.cpp given that I didn't write my own tests for it. . . The public test for processing does look pretty extensive but I'm still not sure.... . Thanks!
i_answer: Usually the public test cases are used to check that your code can "compile" but doesn't guarantee the correctness of your code. However, for processing specifically, it would be very difficult to create your own general test cases (create your own image by generating hundreds of pixels, and calculate which columns or rows to remove, and compare if it is correct). But yes if you really want, you can definitely test your functions individually (not integration tests) by for example, creating a simpler Matrix cost, and provide your own seam, and call find_minimal_vertical_seam(), and see if the results look right.

subject: Segmentation Fault in resize.cpp
content: Hey!. . We continually keep on getting seg faults in our resize.cpp. I'm not sure what is going on, as we followed what was in the specs, but would definitely appreciate some help.
i_answer: Try compiling and running with the address sanitizer.  See https://eecs280staff.github.io/tutorials/setup_asan.html. . Segfault means you have bad access. For example, like the student said, argv may trigger this error. However, it is also possible that during seaming process, you happen to access some elements that are outside the valid range of the image or matrix. You may want to use your debugger and track the execution step by step to find out at which step you got this error so you know which function might be buggy.

subject: Remove Vertical Seam Function Unknown Bug
content: I went office hours and the IA told me to post on here because we were unable to find the bug in our code for our remove vertical seam function.. This is the function:. . .
i_answer: Are you failing the public vertical seam test? If so, what is the differing output?. . Edit: Imagine a sample image with width 5, and for one of the rows, the index of the column that you want to remove is 3. For your code, you did copy the pixels of column 0, 1, 2 to new image, and the corresponding pixel column indices are 0, 1, 2. However, notice that when you code runs into "else" (col==3), you did nothing but set skip to 1. For the next round of for loop, your col will be 4. Then for your if statement, you actually copy the pixel of column (4+skip) which is 5 to new image pixel of column 4. Is this what you expected? You actually want to copy old image column 4 to new image column 3. This is why your function is not working properly.. For debugging tips, you should be able to check the difference between your own image with the correct one, and find out that the next column of the seam column is missing, and then find out where the bug is. Normally we are not expected to tell students which part of the code is wrong directly.

subject: Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row
content: hi! i have a question about Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row(). if the width of the matrix is 1, what should it return? i'm asking because column_start < column_end is in the requires and if the width is 1, then column_start and column_end are both going to have to be zero. i know column_end is exclusive but i'm still confused on this a little bit. how would i call Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row() if width is 1 and column_start needs to be < than column_end?
i_answer: column_start is inclusive and column_end is exclusive, so for your case, the two parameters would be 0 and 1. You may also notice that we have the same inclusive and exclusive requirement for Matrix_min_value_in_row().

subject: Remove_vertical_seam
content: Good afternoon,. . I am having quite a bit of trouble with my remove vertical seam function. Honestly, I have no clue where to start. However, when I use the debugger, I can see that the values are way off. How should I proceed?

Then, step through the function that produced the incorrect seam value. Pay attention to the iteration of the loop where it produces the incorrect value. Where is that coming from? (In your case, it is `Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row`.) How did it produce that incorrect value (in your case, 0)? You would need to fix something in that function (`Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row`) to make it produce the correct value.

subject: seam_carve_width const issue
content: Hi my partner and I have a question regarding seam_carve_width. We originally made MATRIX_HEIGHT as a constant but then realized that cost is changing constantly meaning that it wouldn't be a const. We don't know how to change this to make it compile. Can someone lead us in the right direction?.
i_answer: Variable length arrays on the stack never really made it into the C++ standard because of complications with `sizeof` evaluation and templating parameters. Here, `MATRIX_HEIGHT` is a runtime constant---it might be different when you run it on different images, but every time the function runs, it can't be changed once the image-dependent number is set. What the language really requires here is a compile-time constant, or a "constant expression", a number that the compiler knows for sure and is used by the compiled program for all possible images. Therefore, we need a number that accommodates all the images we promise to accommodate. What's the maximum height of an Image? (Hint: what's the maximum height of a Matrix? How much space do we set aside for each Matrix?) To potentially accommodate input images that have that precise height, **we should set this to the maximum possible height of an Image**. For smaller input images, parts of the array just won't get used. That is fine.

subject: Assertion failed: 0 <= row && row < Matrix_height(mat), line 86
content: My partner and I have spent hours searching through this code to find the reason the assert() fails.If you could give any help or guidance on how to solve or approach this, that would be great.. . // Project UID af1f95f547e44c8ea88730dfb185559d. #include <cassert>#include "processing.h". using namespace std;. // v DO NOT CHANGE v ------------------------------------------------// The implementation of rotate_left is provided for you.// REQUIRES: img points to a valid Image// MODIFIES: *img// EFFECTS:  The image is rotated 90 degrees to the left (counterclockwise).void rotate_left(Image* img) {.   // for convenience  int width = Image_width(img);  int height = Image_height(img);.   // auxiliary image to temporarily store rotated image  Image *aux = new Image;  Image_init(aux, height, width); // width and height switched.   // iterate through pixels and place each where it goes in temp  for (int r = 0; r < height; ++r) {    for (int c = 0; c < width; ++c) {      Image_set_pixel(aux, width - 1 - c, r, Image_get_pixel(img, r, c));    }  }.   // Copy data back into original  *img = *aux;  delete aux;}// ^ DO NOT CHANGE ^ ------------------------------------------------. // v DO NOT CHANGE v ------------------------------------------------// The implementation of rotate_right is provided for you.// REQUIRES: img points to a valid Image.// MODIFIES: *img// EFFECTS:  The image is rotated 90 degrees to the right (clockwise).void rotate_right(Image* img){.   // for convenience  int width = Image_width(img);  int height = Image_height(img);.   // auxiliary image to temporarily store rotated image  Image *aux = new Image;  Image_init(aux, height, width); // width and height switched.   // iterate through pixels and place each where it goes in temp  for (int r = 0; r < height; ++r) {    for (int c = 0; c < width; ++c) {      Image_set_pixel(aux, c, height - 1 - r, Image_get_pixel(img, r, c));    }  }.   // Copy data back into original  *img = *aux;  delete aux;}// ^ DO NOT CHANGE ^ ------------------------------------------------. // v DO NOT CHANGE v ------------------------------------------------// The implementation of diff2 is provided for you.static int squared_difference(Pixel p1, Pixel p2) {  int dr = p2.r - p1.r;  int dg = p2.g - p1.g;  int db = p2.b - p1.b;  // Divide by 100 is to avoid possible overflows  // later on in the algorithm.  return (dr*dr + dg*dg + db*db) / 100;}// ^ DO NOT CHANGE ^ ------------------------------------------------. // ------------------------------------------------------------------// You may change code below this line!. . // REQUIRES: img points to a valid Image.//           energy points to a Matrix.// MODIFIES: *energy// EFFECTS:  energy serves as an "output parameter".//           The Matrix pointed to by energy is initialized to be the same//           size as the given Image, and then the energy matrix for that//           image is computed and written into it.//           See the project spec for details on computing the energy matrix.void compute_energy_matrix(const Image* img, Matrix* energy) {  int width = Image_width(img);  int height = Image_height(img);  Matrix_init(energy, width, height);  Matrix_fill(energy, 0);  for (int i = 0; i < Matrix_height(energy); i++) {        for (int j = 0; j < Matrix_width(energy); j++) {            if (!((i == 0) || (i == height - 1) || (j == 0) || (j == width - 1))) {              Pixel North = Image_get_pixel(img, (i-1), j);              Pixel South = Image_get_pixel(img, (i+1), j);              Pixel East = Image_get_pixel(img, i, (j-1));              Pixel West = Image_get_pixel(img, i, (j+1));                energy->data[i * width +j] = (squared_difference(North, South) + squared_difference(West, East));            }        }    }  Matrix_fill_border(energy, Matrix_max(energy));  }. // REQUIRES: energy points to a valid Matrix.//           cost points to a Matrix.//           energy and cost aren't pointing to the same Matrix// MODIFIES: *cost// EFFECTS:  cost serves as an "output parameter".//           The Matrix pointed to by cost is initialized to be the same//           size as the given energy Matrix, and then the cost matrix is//           computed and written into it.//           See the project spec for details on computing the cost matrix.void compute_vertical_cost_matrix(const Matrix* energy, Matrix *cost) {  int width = Matrix_width(energy);  int height = Matrix_height(energy);  Matrix_init(cost, width, height);  for (int i = 0; i < height; i++) {        for (int j = 0; j < width; j++) {            if (i == 0){              cost->data[i*width + j] = energy->data[i * width + j];            }            else if((j == width - 1)){                cost->data[i * width + j] = energy->data[i * width + j] + min(energy->data[(i-1) * width + j],                                              energy->data[(i-1) * width + (j-1)]);            }            else if(j == 0){              cost->data[i * width + j] = energy->data[i * width + j] + min(energy->data[(i-1) * width + j],                                            energy->data[(i-1) * width + (j+1)]);            }            else{              cost->data[i * width + j] = energy->data[i * width + j] + min(min(energy->data[(i-1) * width + j],                                             energy->data[(i-1) * width + (j+1)]), energy->data[(i-1) * width + (j-1)]);            }        }    }    return;}// REQUIRES: cost points to a valid Matrix//           seam points to an array//           the size of seam is >= Matrix_height(cost)// MODIFIES: seam[0]...seam[Matrix_height(cost)-1]// EFFECTS:  seam serves as an "output parameter".//           The vertical seam with the minimal cost according to the given//           cost matrix is found and the seam array is filled with the column//           numbers for each pixel along the seam, with the pixel for each//           row r placed at seam[r]. While determining the seam, if any pixels//           tie for lowest cost, the leftmost one (i.e. with the lowest//           column number) is used.//           See the project spec for details on computing the minimal seam.// NOTE:     You should compute the seam in reverse order, starting//           with the bottom of the image and proceeding to the top,//           as described in the project spec.void find_minimal_vertical_seam(const Matrix* cost, int seam[]) {  //seam is an array with size = height of cost  int width = Matrix_width(cost);  int height = Matrix_height(cost);  int lowest_column = Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row(cost, (height-1), 0, (width));  int i = (height - 1);  seam[i] = lowest_column;  for (int row = (height-2); row >= 0; --row){    if(lowest_column == 0){      lowest_column = Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row(cost, (row), 0, (lowest_column + 2));      --i;      seam[i] = lowest_column;    }    else if (lowest_column == width -1){      lowest_column = Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row(cost, (row), (lowest_column -1), (lowest_column + 1));      --i;      seam[i] = lowest_column;    }    else{      lowest_column = Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row(cost, (row), (lowest_column -1), (lowest_column + 2));      --i;      seam[i] = lowest_column;    }.     }  }. // REQUIRES: img points to a valid Image with width >= 2//           seam points to an array//           the size of seam is == Image_height(img)//           each element x in seam satisfies 0 <= x < Image_width(img)// MODIFIES: *img// EFFECTS:  Removes the given vertical seam from the Image. That is, one//           pixel will be removed from every row in the image. The pixel//           removed from row r will be the one with column equal to seam[r].//           The width of the image will be one less than before.//           See the project spec for details on removing a vertical seam.// NOTE:     Use the new operator here to create the smaller Image,//           and then use delete when you are done with it.void remove_vertical_seam(Image *img, const int seam[]) {  int width = Image_width(img);  int height = Image_height(img);  Image *aux = new Image;  Image_init(aux, width - 1, height);  for(int i = 0; i < height; ++i){    for(int column = 0; column < width; ++column){      if(column != seam[i]){        aux[i * width + column] = img[i * width + column];    }    }  }  *img = *aux;  delete aux;}. // REQUIRES: img points to a valid Image//           0 < newWidth && newWidth <= Image_width(img)// MODIFIES: *img// EFFECTS:  Reduces the width of the given Image to be newWidth by using//           remove vertical seam. See the spec for details.// NOTE:     Use the new operator here to create Matrix objects, and//           then use delete when you are done with them.void seam_carve_width(Image *img, int newWidth) {  int width = Image_width(img);  int height = Image_height(img);  Matrix* energy = new Matrix;  Matrix* cost = new Matrix;  Matrix_init(energy, height, width);  Matrix_init(cost, height, width);  int *seam = new int[width];  while(width > newWidth){    compute_energy_matrix(img, energy);    compute_vertical_cost_matrix(energy, cost);    find_minimal_vertical_seam(cost, seam);    remove_vertical_seam(img, seam);  delete cost;  delete energy;  delete [] seam;  seam = new int[--width];  }  delete [] seam;}. // REQUIRES: img points to a valid Image//           0 < newHeight && newHeight <= Image_height(img)// MODIFIES: *img// EFFECTS:  Reduces the height of the given Image to be newHeight.// NOTE:     This is equivalent to first rotating the Image 90 degrees left,//           then applying seam_carve_width(img, newHeight), then rotating//           90 degrees right.void seam_carve_height(Image *img, int newHeight) {  rotate_left(img);  seam_carve_width(img, newHeight);  rotate_right(img);}. // REQUIRES: img points to a valid Image//           0 < newWidth && newWidth <= Image_width(img)//           0 < newHeight && newHeight <= Image_height(img)// MODIFIES: *img// EFFECTS:  Reduces the width and height of the given Image to be newWidth//           and newHeight, respectively.// NOTE:     This is equivalent to applying seam_carve_width(img, newWidth)//           and then applying seam_carve_height(img, newHeight).void seam_carve(Image *img, int newWidth, int newHeight) {  seam_carve_width(img, newWidth);  seam_carve_height(img, newHeight);}
i_answer: Hi Ethan, the code is a little difficult to read in this format. I suggest you put your uniqname in your piazza per @64 so we can take a look on AG.. . In general, it's challenging for us to read code and be able to confidently say whether it works or not. What I would suggest it to set a breakpoint on the assert that it fails, and once it fails, look at the call stack (if you use vs code it will be on the lower left hand side of the debugger). That will tell you what function called it and what was the function before the assert failed. . . The best way to solve this issue would be coming to office hours where we can work through the debugger to find the issue.

subject: Resize.cpp reading from file

I read the string notes about file I/O, but the example was printing the words in the file and I didn't know what to do if I just wanted to read from the file into the fstream. . . Let me know!
i_answer: . I am a bit confused about how to read a file using a fstream.. . Please use ifstream instead of fstream. . . What would I do next to actually read from the file into the fstream?. . As the notes say, using .open() for the ifstream variable you have and passing in the filename as an string would open the file. Your next step would be to initialize an image based on this file.. .

subject: Vertical Seam array not working
content: . So  I have written the vertical seam function and I am stuck on a particular part when testing it  where I am pushing back the array with a size of the height of the the image but whenever I set seam[i] where i is initially the last element in the array equal to the column of the lowest row like so..     int col_of_min = 0;    for (int row = costheight -1 ; row > 0; --row) {                // Only to find the start of the bottom row where the min value is        if(row == costheight -1){             col_of_min = starting_point(cost, seam, row,col_of_min);            seam[row] = col_of_min;             }. It never puts it in. I discovered this doing breakpoints but how do I get the array to actually put the data into the array?. . . . .
i_answer: What is `i` meant to represent? What is `row` meant to represent? Why are you writing `seam[i]` and not `seam[row]`?. . Also, I'm fairly certain that the assignment takes place, but because `seam` got passed in as a pointer (and your debugger doesn't know it represents an array), your debugger just shows `*seam`, or `seam[0]`. If you put `seam[i]` in the Watch section of your debugger (it's below all the variables, assuming you use VSCode) or in the [debug console](https://eecs280staff.github.io/tutorials/debugging_guide.html#evaluate-expressions), you should see that change.

One shortcut for you to discover this cause is to add assertions for the REQUIRES clause in the two `Matrix_at` implementations. The function that passed out-of-bound rows or columns to `Matrix_at` has a mistake in it.. . Another hint: the public tests failed as soon as the image is no longer square (5x5).

subject: Size of energy and cost matrix
content: I am wondering if the image matrix must be larger than 3*3. Because the sepc didn’t specify how to deal with matrix smaller than 3*3 when calculating energy matrix. Also, the cost matrix is based on energy matrix and the array seam is based on cost matrix. So can we assume the image matrix is larger than 3*3 for functions in processing.cpp?.
i_answer: . I am wondering if the image matrix must be larger than 3*3. Because the sepc didn’t specify how to deal with matrix smaller than 3*3 when calculating energy matrix. Also, the cost matrix is based on energy matrix and the array seam is based on cost matrix. So can we assume the image matrix is larger than 3*3 for functions in processing.cpp?. . You can't make these assumptions. Your code should work for images of any size.

subject: remove_vertical_seam fails processing_public_tests, tried debugging.
content: . My thought process when writing the code was to skip over the seam in each row. I did this by creating a secondary counter that would be used when setting the pixels of the temporary image. This counter would "lag behind" the column for loop when it encountered the seam. And thus when setting the pixels of the new image they would be set to the values of the old image that come later on. It is not working however, and I am at a loss. Any help is greatly appreciated.
i_answer: That particular test actually failed because your `Image_init` didn't read in the correct 4x5 dog image correctly. I found your root cause, and it has to do with the fact that you can read square images fine (5x5 dog) but not non-square images (4x5). Check your `Image_init`. Maybe you got the width and height mixed up?

subject: Vertical_Cost Crabster Not Passing
content: My vertical cost function passed for dog and horses but not for crabster. I looked at the crabster_cost_out.txt and crabster_cost_correct.txt and it showed that three seemingly random numbers were different(below). Anybody have an idea what went wrong?. image.png
i_answer: I found your root cause on your latest autograder submission using **conditional breakpoints**. Here's what you (and others encountering problems that look similar) can do:. . - Familiarize yourself with conditional breakpoints [here](https://eecs280staff.github.io/tutorials/debugging_guide.html#conditional-breakpoints).. - Find the first number in your program's output that does not match the corresponding number in the correct output.. - Set up a conditional breakpoint where the condition is "we found that first incorrect number", like `cost == 10839`.. - Debug the program. It should stop at the conditional breakpoint where your first incorrect number was determined. Figure out how the incorrect number came to be by inspecting the variables and thinking through your logic. If you're in VSCode, you can add expressions to the "watch" pane between "call stack" and "variables" to evaluate them. For example, you can add the expression `*Matrix_at(cost, r-1, c-1)` to the Watch section and see what it evaluates to.. . In the author's specific case, there was a suspicious constant in `Matrix_min_value_in_row`. All the costs were greater than 10000. What would happen in this case?

subject: Edge Case Possibility
content: My partner and I were looking at edge cases that might affect the processing functions (compute_vertical_cost_matrix, find_minimal_vertical_seam, and remove_vertical_seam) and noticed that if the final edited image/matrix that the user desires were to be of dimensions (1 by x, x by 1, or 1 by 1) then it would break the functions because the bounds of some of our nested loops are set to width/height - 1. . . Would we have to code to protect against this possible private case where the final size of the image has at least one dimension of 1? I can provide additional clarifying information if necessary.
i_answer: This is a good question. Your program should still work if either or both dimensions for the image is 1. . . . then it would break the functions because the bounds of some of our nested loops are set to width/height - 1. . If your for loop starts at 0 (or 1), since it should end at width - 1 = 0 in this case, it will immediately terminate the for loop. If this is not what is happening, I suggest carefully looking at your code and see how you can change your for loops (as an example, there might be more things to look at). I can tell you that you won't need to consider this as a standalone edge case if your functions' implementation closely follows the spec.

subject: Remove Vertical Seam Issue
content: Hi, I'm having some issues in my implementation of the remove vertical seam function.. . I don't know how much detail is permissible on here, but I'm essentially creating a temporary image with the width shortened by one. Then, I'm using a for loop up to the seam to set the pixels on temp on the left side of the seam to the same pixels from img. Then another for loop to set the pixels on temp on the right side of the seam to pixels on img + 1. Then I set img equal to temp. . . However, I've been getting some really weird behavior out of my function. For starters running that code for dog outputs this strange image:. . . . subject: Can someone help me figure out how I can fix from here for Image_print()?
content: . I'm confused on what function I should use if Image_get_pixel() isn't the correct one or are my parameters wrong?
i_answer: You're on the right track. You're currently trying to get and print the same pixel 3 times. However, you should be printing each value (r, g, b) of the single pixel. The call to Image_get_pixel gives you a Pixel struct. You just need to print the 3 values in that Pixel in order.

subject: Resize error on autograder
content: When I submit my resize.cpp, the output it gives is the error output for not being able to open dog.ppm. However when I run the same command from my terminal, I don’t get an error. Can anyone point me in the right direction as to what could be causing this?
i_answer: You're using an fstream instead of an ifstream. If you make that change, then I think the issue will be resolved.. . Explanation (if you're interested): Using an ifstream uses read access for a file, while fstream also request write access. For obvious reasons, we don't want you to overwrite the image files, so write access if denied, and AG tells you it can't open the file.

subject: Error in Autograder with two functions test_min_col_END_OF_COLUMN and test_min_value_END_OF_COLUMN
content: Hi, so I am having an issue trying to figure out where in my code I messed up or in my test I messed up because when I use the debugger to run of the terminal to run, it runs perfectly fine with no errors but when I turned these two tests into the autograder I get a false positive? . I don't know how you access my code in the autograder but some assistance would be nice otherwise I'm just going to delete these two tests and call it a day.. . . . . Also if my make test completely ran through even the processing public tests, does that mean that my functions , when put into the processing public tests, work , expect for obviously unit testing.
i_answer: "False positive" means that the test case fails when run with a correct solution, meaning there's an issue with some of your assert statements.. . In line 300 of your Matrix_tests, I believe the correct output of the function would be 1, not 4 (because column_end is supposed to exclusive from the RME, so we really should be looking at columns 0-3, inclusive).. . Similarly, in line 382, I believe the correct output should be 12, not 9, for the same reason.

subject: Seam Undefined and Sizeof errors
content: So I have ran my code through CAEN just to see my errors more clearly and I get this.. . So I know that it tells me that sizeof(seam) gives the size of int* but how else am I supposed to find the size of the seam. i_answer: Recall that there is no function in C++ to directly return how large an array is. The sizeof() function returns how much space in memory an object takes up, not how many elements are in a container.. . I would not worry about asserting any requirements for the size of the seam array.

subject: Get Pixel test failing make
content: Edit: we're supposed to use pixel_equal() to compare pixels.. . Hi,. . I'm writing test cases for Image_tests.cpp and it looks like my get pixel is failing when trying to make. This is basically what my code looks like:. . . ASSERT_EQUAL((Image_get_pixel(img, row, col)), premadePixel);. . . However, it is throwing this error:. . . If anyone could please help, that would be much appreciated. Thanks!
i_answer: assert_equal() is kind of a shorthand for ==, so it can only compare types that are comparable with ==. Since structs don't apply to ==, you can't compare Pixel using it. you'd have to access each member variable individually to compare the two or use Pixel_equal from Image_tests_helpers.h

subject: No Image test cases are running
content: While my matrix test cases are running, none of my image test cases are running (in the autograder), and I'm not sure why this is happening.
i_answer: On line 193 of your image_tests you're comparing pixel equality, but the testing framework doesn't know how to directly compare pixels using == since they're a custom struct. Instead, use the given helper function Pixel_equal() for pixel equality and assert() that it's true.

subject: Copying back into original image remove_vertical_seam
content: Hi I was wondering what to do with the remaining values of the original image that got removed when I copy the copy into the original. Do I just set those to 0? So there would be a column of 0's on the right due to the removed column of seam?
i_answer: Per the spec, "You should copy into a smaller auxiliary Image and then back into the original, because there is no way to change the width of an existing image... . To remove the seam, copy the image one row at a time, first copying the part of the row before the seam (green), skipping that pixel, and then copying the rest (orange).". . Original. . Seam Removed. . If you're just using an algorithm to write each row into a new image, do you need to do anything with those cut pixels? For that matter, what should happen to the original image?

subject: Qs about copying matrix
content: I have a question about address dereference. In the rotate_right function we are provided with, can we also say img = aux (without the * for both) to let the the img pointer point to the address where the aux pointer points to, which is the aux matrix? Also, when we delete aux, are we only deleting the pointer, or are we also deleting the data in the aux matrix?. .
i_answer: Note that img is being passed by value, not by reference. So setting the pointer to be another pointer in this context is somewhat meaningless. Deferencing img and setting it to be equal to the data of aux is acceptable. When you do delete aux, that deletes the underlying data aux is associated with on the heap.

subject: How to interpret Perf report
content: I ran into an issue with horses taking too long to load so I utilized Perf. I have this report but am still unsure how to interpret it to see which functions are taking more time than they should be. (The table is also of crabster as horses was taking too long to test)

Matrix at,  height, and width also seem to be taking quite long. You should probably look into those functions first and see if you can optimize them.

subject: initialize energy to be the same size of image
content: . I currently do not understand how to initialize energy to the size of the image that we are inputting. I am getting an error about an unassigned long being used to initialize a long. i_answer: Also, you can't access the width like that, or any other member like that outside of the very function that struct is defined in; it's not respecting the interfaces (the autograder marks points off for this). You need to call the function that accesses the width of img to use it.

subject: Do we need Assert statements in our functions?

For example, in the matrix init function, do I HAVE to assert the width is greater than 0 and less than the max matrix width? Could I submit my project without these assert statements in my functions? And will it pass the private tests?
i_answer: As the student answer suggests, having assert statements is not required. Assert statements can help ensure you’re passing in expected input into a function and help you debug more easily. I.E if an assert statement fails in matrix row, you know either your test case was incorrect or some other member variable of mat was not properly set.

subject: Student UB testing autograder error for Image.cpp and Matrix.cpp

subject: What to set as image in Image_fill?
content: I'm working on the Image_fill function, and to fill the image with each pixel, I call the Image_set_pixel function. i_answer: Image_set_pixel() gets a pointer to an Image, and img is already a pointer to an image, so you can simply pass img into Image_set_pixel

subject: Writing Image_init()function
content: How do I write test function for Image_init(), do I use ASSERT_EQUAL or ASSERT_TRUE to compare?
i_answer: Yes, you can use Assert_equal() to confirm it has been set to the correct height and width. You can also use Image_get_pixel() to confirm all pixels have been correctly initialized based on input.. . How you use the testing helper functions is up to you, based on what you are trying to test.

subject: compute_vertical_cost_matrix what's cost of (2,0)

i_answer: Yes, if you are on the leftmost of the grid, then you should find the min of col and col+1. Similarly, if you are on the rightmost of the grid, you should find the min of col-1 and col.

subject: Unknown Print Error
content: Good evening, I have been playing with this issue for days and cannot find the issue. I sat in the OH queue for an hour and did not move past halfway. Also, why are you reading into trash and then trash2 in the beginning? There is only one piece of junk in the beginning ("P3"). See if any of those suggestions work!

subject: A little confused about what Image_set_pixel is supposed to do

i_answer: You want to set one pixel, and each pixel has three colors associated with it. Each image has also three channels (matrices) associated with it. One pixel represents one element in the image. Your guess about calling Matrix_at() is correct. Think about what matrices you want to set a value to and what values.

subject: Initializing an array
content: Screen_Shot_2023-01-31_at_6.07.23_PM.png. I'm trying to create a seam array for my seam_carve_width function and I'm keep getting a compilation error. It says I can't initialize the array with the size of the height of img. Then when I don't declare it with a certain size, I get a different error. Do you know why this is?
i_answer: To initialize the seam array, you should use the constant `MAX_MATRIX_HEIGHT` defined in `matrix.h`. The length of the array must be fixed at the compiled time. `img->height` might not be known at the compiled time so that's why it gives you the error.

subject: Testing Matrix_row

i_answer: When initializing ptr, it has to point to a const int object. For example, you could say const int *ptr = &height; where height is an int object.

subject: Processed images are skewed diagonally after seam carve
content: My processing.cpp is able to correctly find seams and remove them, but acts very strange after applying the seam_carve algorithms. The images they produce have the correct dimensions and are able to effectivly carve (to my belief, from the horses image), but are skewed diagonally, and I am currently stuck debugging this. horses_300x382.out.ppm. crabster_50x45.out_copy.ppm Screen_Shot_2023-01-31_at_4.50.19_PM.png. . Below is my implementation for seam_carve_width. . void seam_carve_width(Image *img, int newWidth) {. .   assert(0 < newWidth && newWidth <= Image_width(img));.   int widthChange = Image_width(img) - newWidth;. .   for ( int carve = 0; carve < widthChange; ++carve ) {. .     Image* resize = new Image;.     Image_init(resize, Image_width(img), Image_height(img));. .     Matrix* tempEnergy = new Matrix;.     Matrix_init(tempEnergy, Image_width(resize), Image_height(resize));.     compute_energy_matrix(resize, tempEnergy);.     .     Matrix* tempCost = new Matrix;.     Matrix_init(tempCost, Image_width(resize), Image_height(resize));.     compute_vertical_cost_matrix(tempEnergy, tempCost);. .     int tempSeam[MAX_MATRIX_HEIGHT];.     find_minimal_vertical_seam(tempCost, tempSeam);.     delete tempEnergy;.     delete tempCost;. .     remove_vertical_seam(resize, tempSeam);. .     *img = *resize;.     delete resize;. .   }. . }
i_answer: A followup... is there a way to test seam_carve_width as opposed to seam_carve ? The issue could also be in one of these two (my implementations): . . void seam_carve_height(Image *img, int newHeight) {.   .   rotate_left(img);.   seam_carve_width(img, newHeight);.   rotate_right(img);.   . }. . void seam_carve(Image *img, int newWidth, int newHeight) {.   .   seam_carve_width(img, newWidth);.   seam_carve_height(img, newHeight);. . }

subject: Help with Time
content: Is there anyway that someone can help me figure out why my code is taking really long? It keeps timing out on auto grader and even on CAEN. When I run perf its says that Matrix_row is taking a really long time but I cant seem to find the issue after looking at this for a really long time. Thanks . . uniqname: deankatz
i_answer: Performance issue: You use a for loop for your Matrix_at() calculations. This will cause a performance issue for you. It can be achieved by pointer arithmetics (from lab 3). Look at the 1-d array and 2-d matrix on spec, and try to do a couple of examples of translating what the index of the 1-d array would be in terms of row and column for a matrix. . . There's also a bug on line 53 of resize.cpp. . seam_carve(img,desired_width,Image_height(img));. Here, you never consider desired_height for seam_carve().

subject: matrix_row
content: I don't understand how this failed the private test. The test made a 5x5 matrix and a pointer to (2,3), and this code returned 1 instead of 2. My logic is that ptr - &mat->data[0] would return the index of the element, and integer dividing by the width returns the row since it rounds down. Where did I go wrong?
i_answer: Can you try mat->data, it returns a pointer to first element in data?. I wonder if its doing the operations in &mat->data[0] in a different order than you expect.

subject: Removing Vertical seam
content: I read the FAQ for removing vertical seam and I'm still a little confused. It says that we'll make a new matrix and then change the pointer output to point to that new matrix. Does this mean we make two arrays for each row (one before and one after the seam), and then copy them into a third array (eventually returned by changing the pointer) that is initialized with a width of one less than the original image? This would make sense to me except for the fact that I thought we were supposed to delete anything we make with the new operator, but in this case, we'd be returning something created with the new operator?
i_answer: I would think of it as initializing a new matrix with the correct dimensions, and going through the old matrix and copying the values that are needed into that matrix.. . Then once you are done you can set the old matrix to the new matrix, and delete the new matrix.

subject: seam_carve_width - update matrices
content: How to update the energy and cost matrices in seam_carve every time we remove the minimal value?

subject: Processing test
content: . Does anyone what do these mean?
i_answer: It means you have deleted a pointer twice, which causes a double-free error. Whenever you dynamically allocate some memory with new, you need to free(delete) that piece of memory after your use. And it should be freed exactly once.. You could set a breakpoint and step through your code to see where you called delete on a pointer that had already been deleted.

subject: Check null
content: Hello,. . When implementing functions, for example, "void remove_vertical_seam(Image *img, const int seam[])," do we need to check if seam is null?
i_answer: No, as stated by the "REQUIRES" comments, "seam points to an array", so you do not need to check if it's null.

subject: resize output file error
content: when I run the resize program with the right number of arguments but the argument that holds the output file does not have the name of an existing file, running resize makes a file with that name and outputs the image.ppm there. Is this intended?
i_answer: Yes, this is correct. The third to last argument is the name of the file that resize will output to. If it exists, it overwrites the file, but if it doesn't, it creates a new one.

subject: compute_vertical_cost_matrix clarification
content: is cost() a function we are allowed to use under the compute_vertical_cost_matrix function? i'm just a bit confused because it's not written as a function in the processing.cpp file but it's given in the formula we are supposed to use here:. . cost(r, c) = energy(r, c) + min(cost(r-1, c-1),                                cost(r-1, c),                                cost(r-1, c+1))
i_answer: It is just written like that to explain, that isn't actual code.. . Let (r,c) be the element in the rth row and cth column. It is saying that cost of (r,c) is equal to the energy of (r,c) plus the smallest cost out of the three elements above (r,c). The three elements above should already be initialized because you are moving "down" the array ("down" in quotes because the array is really 1 dimensional)

subject: test case fail only shows up on autograder (ag)
content: when running test cases on terminal or xcode debugger there are no failures. but on ag it shows up as failure and shows a 2x2 matrix with the row 0 col 1 element as 32514. row 0 col 1 element should be 0 (?). . .
i_answer: The elements of the matrix that you do not manually set are not equal to zero, but rather have undefined behavior. Different computers can initialize ints in arrays differently, and while your computer gives a default value of 0, the autograder gives a different default value.. . You need to either initialize your array with 0's when you create it, or use Matrix_fill to fill it with 0s in the beginning of the test case.. . See @681 for an instructor answer about this.

subject: private style tests
content: Are there some private style tests for project 2 or are they all public?
i_answer: All of the style requirements are at the bottom of each Autograder submit. We don't hide any style guidelines from you in any project in this course, the Autograder will always tell you if you have a style issue.

subject: Ubuntu won't let me make the file
content: Does anyone know why I'm getting this error in ubuntu when using the make command?. . . .
i_answer: It looks like you are in the correct directory, but make sure that you pluralize test!. . ```. make Image_public_tests.exe. ```

subject: Timed Out Errors for Crabster and Horses test cases
content: Both horses and crabster tests time out when I run them on autograder and I am not sure how to fix this. Crabster doesn't take too long on VS Code (less than a minute) and every test ends up passing but Horses never terminates. . . I have tried. 1. Debugging to see which lines are causing the code to run for so long. In Crabster, the function ". compute_energy_matrix" in "seam carve width" takes the longest time to execute. In Horses, it takes a long time to terminate the "image_init" function that is inside the "load_image" function.. 2. Removing cout statements and making sure I delete every time I use the "new" key word. . Uniqname: anushac
i_answer: Typically time out means you probably use too many loops or nested loops when you don't actually need them.. For your case, I see that you used nested for loops for image_get_pixel() and image_set_pixel(). Think about which function you may call inside these two functions to access the element of the given row and column "directly". This should save you a lot of time.

subject: passing crabster seam carve 50x45 but not 70x35
content: Hello, for some reason I am passing crabster seam carve 50x45 but not 70x35 in the public tests (the error being that carved_img does not equal carved_image_correct). I am super confused about why this could be happening. its hard to imagine a way to debug through it as its such a large image. . . Any insight would be helpful!.
i_answer: I would say add cout statements in seam_carve_width and seam_carve_height to see how many times those are called. If I remember correctly, seam_carve_width should be called 4 times and seam_carve_height should be called 10 times.

subject: Image_Init not working
content: I'm a bit confused on the Image_Init function in Image.cpp. The public test that we ran didn't output properly and I think that it may be because of the init function. The output and code is down below. . . . .
i_answer: Having the `string PPM` was a great idea to read in the "junk" value of P3. However, remember that the format of this particular type of ppm file is P3, then width and height, *then 255*, and then we get to the pixels. It doesn't look like you're reading in the "junk" value of 255 and instead treating that as a pixel value.

subject: Using seam carving algorithm
content: How would I actually use the image resizing program to resize real images? Is there a way I would be able to convert images I have in and out of ppm format?
i_answer: This application allows you to convert and view PPM files if I remember correctly: https://www.gimp.org/. . Also, I haven't personally tried this out but this repository can do something similar: https://github.com/oalejel/resize-GUI. . I think it only works on Mac though.

subject: array_equal test helpers
content: How would array_equal be used during unit testing? I've had no use for it even thought I feel like I'm done testing every function. Am I missing something?
i_answer: Here is an example from processing_public_tests.cpp of how it is used:. . What they do here is they load_seam from the seam output file, and then compare it to what the correct seam should be. Though you could also do this by just creating a stream with the correct seam and then comparing it to the file.. . Also, you don't have to use every helper function if you were wondering.

subject: Energy
content: Is energy the red, green, and blue added together? I'm not sure why the number in the spec is so high (1470) when the maximum pixel can only be 255 and 3*255 is less than 1470.
i_answer: The energy of the pixel is given by the equation energy(X) = squared_difference(N, S) + squared_difference(W, E) as given in the specs. The code for squared_difference is at the top of processing.cpp and involves subtracting the red of the first pixel from the red of the second and squaring it. This is repeated for green and blue and then all three values are added together and divided by 100.

However, when I turn it into Autograder to check, the same code passes all the processing public tests for dog, crabster, and horses. Which of these should I look at to evaluate how my code actually functions?. . . .
i_answer: This is certainly a weird issue but the Autograder is always the ground truth. I'm not sure why your machine is saying that you failed the tests when the Autograder says something different. Maybe try running the code on CAEN?

i_answer: make test is actually telling you that there is no difference between dog_4x5.out.ppm and dog_4x5.correct.ppm, since there is nothing returned after the command is run (both in make test and in your manual run of diff.. . When diff doesn't return an output, it means there are no differences, so you're good.

subject: Failed public test - find_minimal_vertical_seam function
content: We failed the public test case for find_minimal_vertical_seam function and we could not figure out what was wrong with our code. . . We have tried: . 1. Use the breakpoint and debugger but we could not see how the variables are updated and it does not seem to reach the conclusion. . 2. The output of this function returns a random number (junk in memory) . 3. Write different test cases by hand, including one element in the matrix, 5x5 matrix, 3x5 matrix,.. and it all passes the test cases we made. . 4. We wrote lots of test cases for Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row and it passes all the test cases, so we believe that this function works well in find_minimal_vertical_seam function.. 5. In our code, we also account for the features of column_start (inclusive) and column_end (exclusive) . . Here's our code and our uniqname are "swarida" and "danng": . .
i_answer: There should be no return value for this function. When you are debugging, can you see the seam values as you're stepping through line by line in this function?

subject: resize.cpp, a segmentation fault (core dumped) on CAEN
content: The code would compile and run to get the correct output on my personal computer, but when I connect it to CAEN to test it, I run into a "segmentation fault (core dumped)" error:. . . This is the code I have:. . . Does the problem lie in the resize.cpp file, or do you think it might originate from one of my other functions?. . Also, is there a way to run the debugger on CAEN?
i_answer: Segmentation fault normally means you're indexing out-of-bounds somewhere. Your personal computer may just not be listing an error when you run into the issue.. . To debug on CAEN, you could try to use the Remote-SSH VSCode extension to ssh into CAEN and run your normal VSCode debugger.

subject: Can I assume that the rest of the function are implemented correctly when testing one function?
content: Say I am testing the function Matrix_init the only way I can test this function by assuming that the Matrix_height and Matrix_row are not implemented correctly is by using the -> operator and accessing the struct member directly which would not respect the interface. So can I assume that the rest of the function are implemented correctly when testing one function?
i_answer: You can assume that yes. The point of abstraction is that you can rely/assume upon the correct implementation of something else.

subject: confused testing image_init
content: Anyone have advice on how to test image_init? Currently have my function completed but am lost on how to test it
i_answer: There are two image init functions. The first one should be quite straightforward since you're assigning data to width and height and the matrices of the data. There should be two kinds of get width and height functions you have written in image and matrix .cpp files which would be handy here. . The second one is a bit more complicated, and I recommend you look at the public tests for an example. It shows one quite clearly and you can modify from that to get some edge cases.

subject: Closing Matrix in Resize.cpp
content: Hi team, I have a quick question about the Resize.cpp, so I open the Image at the beginning of the file and close it all the way at the very end; however, in the cases where there is an invalid input, I print out the error message and then return a non-zero value to exit the program. I just have one main concern though- will this cause an allocation error? I am thinking this because the Matrix isn't being closed if the program is being exited early due to an error, thus leaving the Matrix still open. .
i_answer: You can add a delete to every if statement before you exit your program.

subject: resize.cpp not compiling on autograder
content: Hi,. . my resize.cpp isn't compiling and I don't know what I did wrong. It says "cat: dog_4x5.out.ppm: No such file or directory"
i_answer: cat is a command for reading files, it's included in the error because the autograder uses the cat command to read files. . . The problem is that in resize.cpp, you never output the new image as a file. At the end of resizing, make sure you create an ofstream and output the image into it. If you need help with file inputs and outputs, check out these notes.

subject: processing.cpp not passing horse test
content: The processing public test horses is the only one not passing for me on autograder, and I don't really understand the output. Here's what it shows:. .
i_answer: std:bad_alloc suggests some kind of memory leak. I would recommend setting up the address sanitizer on your machine and running with horses locally.. . You can also use a debugger to step through seam_carve with horses as input and see if anything looks strange.. . Edit: you can also look through your code and make sure that every object you create with "new" is deleted with "delete".

subject: Failing UB Checks?
content: I passed all the public tests when I ran them on my computer but the autograder is saying this, and it's not saying where the error is so I don't know how to fix it. Anyone else with the same issue?
i_answer: Failing the UB tests suggests some memory leaks in your code. You should make sure that any objects you create with "new" are deleted with "delete".. . I would also recommend setting up the address sanitizer to help find the leaks.

subject: Autograder error with img-> red_channel, green_channel,blue_channel
content: So I know that I'm obviously not supposed to use the img->red_channel now with this error but I am confused on how to fix it. I have tried creating a function that just reads in the img->red_channel but then all my test functions completely break. Any tips on how to quickly resolve this issue?.
i_answer: If you need to access a specific pixel in an Image object, call Image_get_pixel instead. This will return a Pixel object and .r will give you the red value. Calling Matrix_at on img->red_channel does not respect the interface.

subject: #include  not working

i_answer: Add using namespace std; after your include statements so you can type string instead of std::string

subject: Why is ptr undefined in this?
content: I am trying to set up values for row and col for my for loop in Matrix_fill, but I am unable to use ptr because it says it is undefined despite pointer being a constant integer. We have tried using * and & to access ptr but it isn't working. What am I doing wrong?. . .
i_answer: The function signature reads as:. void Matrix_fill(Matrix* mat, int value). Since you're using ptr as if it's defined in the first line, and it also isn't defined as a parameter or a variable outside of the function, it really isn't defined.. . Think about what you actually mean and are trying to do with this ptr.

subject: seam_carve_width

subject: Error with declaring an array with variable size
content: Hi,. I'm having this error and i'm not sure how to solve it. Im pretty sure I should be able to declare it like this because for each image the height will be a constant value.. . Is there another issue causing the error or am I implementing wrong?
i_answer: The height attribute of an image will not be constant, hence why the compiler is complaining. Instead, use the constant MAX_MATRIX_HEIGHT.

subject: Project 2 Processing.cpp compute_energy_matrix function
content: I had a question about the processing.cpp compute_energy_matrix function. It tells us to fill the energy Matrix with values of 0 so I did that by calling the Matrix_fill function. However, if I look at the example on the project specs, it doesn't have the values as 0 so I wasn't sure if I missed a step regarding this.. . Also, when it says to fill the border with the highest energy calculated, are we supposed to fill the border of the energy Matrix or the image?
i_answer: The reason it isn't filled with 0s is because it shows you the final energy matrix, filling it with 0s is just the first step.. . You should fill the border of the energy Matrix with the highest energy calculated.

i_answer: The only way you could really see what's going on is using your debugger to step through a small image like dog, and see where it's going wrong, or just comparing outputs of your files.. . Some things I can suggest is making sure your rotate function works correctly, and that your seam_carve_height function correctly rotates and unrotates before and after carving it.

subject: Errors running resize.exe
content: I was able to run resize.exe correctly and was getting the correct output. I changed some other code and now when I run resize with the correct number of command line arguments nothing happens, and when I run it with the wrong number of  arguments I get this error:. . . . I would debug it but I don't know how to debug when command line arguments are required and do not know what else to try. . Thank you!
i_answer: When you run resize with the wrong number of arguments, your code is accessing memory out of bounds (usually something like int a = std::atoi(argv[5)). This is why you're seeing this error.. . For this project, you don't need to worry about us passing incorrect, or an invalid number of arguments.

subject: Image_init: filling the Matrix channels
content: For the. . image_init(Image* img, std::istream& is). function, after I extract the file type and width and height, how can I go through each "line" one by one (to get each pixel) to the end of the istream? Should this involve a loop or something else (what method)? I tried looking online and on piazza but I couldn't clearly figure out what to use. Thanks!
i_answer: It would be the use of iteration of a for loop (double) to parse through the matrixes and set each pixel within the Image matrix. Additionally, the istream parameter will keep reading in (skipping white space), until it fails, and once it fails, then the compiler will be able to tell there nothing left = end of the file.

subject: Why does this error show up when I try to run and debunk my code?
