subject: Confused About processing.cpp Error in Autograder
content: I am getting this error message on autograder for my processing.cpp that I don't quite understand. Could someone take a look at it for me? Uniqname is: kathli . . . Thank you so much!
i_answer: The function Image_equal() uses your Image_get_pixel() implementation to compare two Images pixel by pixel. I'd double-check your Image_get_pixel. It looks like you're mixing up two colors.

subject: style error in CAEN
content: what does "deep nested block [size|P3] Block depth of 5 exceeds limit of 4" mean?
i_answer: It means you have too much nesting going on. A triple-nested for-loop, or an if-statement within a double-nested for-loop, has one additional layer of depth when compared to a double-nested for-loop. You'll have to get rid of one layer at the location specified by the style check while keeping functionality the same to pass the style check.

subject: Matrix_at() for data member variable
content: how do you use matrix.at() for the data member variable when iterating through the width using i?. . is it just Matrix_at(cost, i, i)?
i_answer: If you plan to iterate through only one row, keep the row number constant and pass i in as the column.. . E.g. (if I wanted to iterate through only row 0). . for (int i = 0; i < Matrix_width(mat); ++i){.    Matrix_at(mat, 0, i);. }. . If you want to iterate through the entire matrix, consider using a double for loop.. .

subject: How do you read in arguments into parameters?
content: Hi, so I am working on resize.cpp and I am having trouble with how the arguments are read into the parameters that we use in the file. Is it possible to show an example of how an argument might get into a specific argument you want? for instance, reading a file name into a string variable..
i_answer: there is a good lecture example but basically,int main(int argc, char **argv){  // Main program here}Notice the parameters in main, argc is the size of argv.argv is an array of C-strings. argv[0] in the sake of the project is going to be “resize.exe”…Long story short you should watch the end of lecture 5 I believe. It will make a lot of sense especially if you watch DeOrios lecture.

subject: Using Matrix_test_helpers in Image_tests
content: Are we allowed to use #include Matrix_test_helpers.h in Image_tests.cpp?
i_answer: Yes, but be aware of respecting the public interface when testing Image functions (in other words, when testing image, don't test matrix functions)

subject: how to get output of cost/energy matrix and seam
content: My assertions for the cost and energy matrices are failing for dog and I'd like to test how the output differs using diff. How do I get my output as a txt so I can compare it with the correct output (I see it's given as a txt). . . Similarly, how can I do this for seam?
i_answer: ./processing_public_tests.exe dog > my_output.txtdiff (or sdiff) my output.txt output.txt. . Also, from the spec: "The seam carving tests work sequentially and stop at the first deviation from correct behavior so that you can identify the point at which your code is incorrect."

subject: losing points in "mutation testing suite"
content: hello, in the autograder I am losing 1 point each for Student Matrix Tests and Student Image tests in the mutation testing suite. . . . . I am not sure what this means though? Would it be possible to tell me why this might be happening?
i_answer: You need to expose one more bug for each test suite. This means you have to extend your matrix and image test cases to cover more scenarios. You can find some good hints on piazza on how to do so.

subject: Matrix_board_fill testing error with assertion failure
content: When I try to run the Matix_tests. cpp, it showed that the matrix_board_fill test failed with the assertion. But I am confused as to why it failed, and couldn't find the error. How could I fix this problem?.
i_answer: You seem to be calling Matrix_width and Matrix_height before you initialize your matrix.

subject: Iterating Loops using pointers
content: I want to iterate through a row in matrix.cpp. When you want to index using a pointer you are going to set the pointer equal to data for example. Because of the way pointers behave, you are going to want to use ++ptr to get the first element of data (basically data[0] ) instead of ptr++ correct?
i_answer: You certainly can iterate over a row as the student answer describes above. However, I would highly suggest using matrix at instead of relying upon ptr arithmetic.

subject: Ternary Statements
content: The autograder just flagged me for too deep of nesting in one of my functions. Am i allowed to use a ternary statement to go around this restriction?
i_answer: You can use the ternary operator. Personally, I would highly suggest against it. Typically many style guides you’ll encounter strongly advise against its usage due to readability issues. As the student answer suggests, you might want to investigate helper functions.

subject: What value of the N/S/E/W pixels am I using to compute the energy matrix

i_answer: per the student answer, use `squared_difference()` -- if you look at the function implementation, this is the sum of square differences between two pixels' RGB values.

subject: Don't understand Image_set_pixel and Image_get_pixel
content: Hi, I don't really understand how Pixel works and how we use r g and b in our implementations for Image_get_pixel and Image_set_pixel. I also don't really understand how to implement those two functions. Can someone lead us in the right direction?
i_answer: The Pixel struct is a convenient way to store the r,g,b values(for example, you can alternatively use a vector pair inside a vector pair to store r,g,b values). . . Your first Image_init function initializes the red, green, and blue channels with dimensions. Your second Image_init function will fill these matrices with the associated red, green, and blue values. Alternatively, Image_set_pixel can also fill in the matrices by taking in a color(Pixel struct with an r,g, and b value).. . After you have filled these matrices with values, you would want a function that can get these values(image_get_pixel). . . To set the pixel, you are going to change the color_channel matrices to the r,g, or b component of the color.. . To get the pixel, you are taking data from the matrices and storing them into the pixel's r, g, or b variables.

subject: identifier "red_channel" is undefined
content: void Image_set_pixel(Image* img, int row, int column, Pixel color) {. assert(img != NULL);. assert(row >= 0 && row < Image_height(img));. assert(column >= 0 && column < Image_width(img));. . int red = color.r;. int green = color.g;. int blue = color.b;. . *Matrix_at(img->*red_channel,row,column) = red;. }. . I have this implementation for Image_set_pixel, but my compiler says there is an error when I try to use img->*red_channel, saying it is undefined. I have tried so many things but nothing seems to work, any help?
i_answer: I converted your post to private since you're sharing code. In the future, please share your code only in private posts -- you don't want anyone stealing your ideas!. . Recall that the * operator is the dereference operator, and we use it on pointers to get the objects they're pointing to. However, img->red_channel returns a Matrix, not a Matrix pointer. Matrix_at() takes in a Matrix pointer, not a Matrix. Is there another operator you can use to get a pointer to (img->red_channel)? I recommend you review Lab 3 for tips.

subject: pointer to new Matrix
content: Hi, I'm running into a problem where I used the given test_fill_basic test module and initialized a 2x3 matrix with all values of 43. After deleting mat at the end of that test module, I made a test module for a more complicated Matrix_print test. When i initialized my new matrix, this time a 3x3 one, assigning row 0, column 1 to the value of 42, it looks like my mat pointer returned to the original matrix initialized in the test_fill_basic module, printing the 43s with my reassigned 42 value. Should this be expected?
i_answer: It sounds like the memory used for your first matrix was reused for the second one, hence the "43" values left over. Your operating system may reuse a pool of memory without first "clearing" its values for the sake of performance. However, this behavior isn't guaranteed to happen on all platforms (or even with consecutive runs of the test on your computer). Thus, you want to make sure your tests initialize all values in a Matrix before checking all values (which is what Matrix_print() technically does) to avoid non-determinism. Is there a function you can use to quickly initialize all values to something?

subject: Seam Carving Algorithm
content: When implementing the seam carving algorithm, should the cost and energy matrices be recalculated each time one column is erased?  Or should we carve each time with respect to the original costs and energies of each pixel?

subject: what is "Implicit conversion loses integer precision: 'long' to 'int'"
content: yellow error on xcode that comes up when trying to implement Matrix_row function of matrix.cpp
i_answer: Long is an integer type with higher precision (it stores more bits), so when it's converted to int, it loses precision.. . I would not worry about the warning for the specific functions you are implementing. However, to fix this warning, you can cast your result to int before returning it, such as. . int foo() {. 	long x = 1;. 	return (int)x;. }

subject: Accessing Image Members in Processing.cpp

subject: Accessing Pixel Member Variabls

subject: Accessing Member Variables
content: I just wanted to get some clarification on the rules for "Respecting the Interface".  The spec says only certain functions in Matrix.cpp should access the data member directly, does this also apply to the width and height variables?  By this I mean in either Matrix or Image, whenever we have img->height or mat->width, should it be replaced with the respective access function (i.e. Image_height(img))?
i_answer: Yes. Since you've defined height and width functions which retrieve the dimensions of an image (or matrix) for you, respecting the interface would mean using these functions whenever you need to access the height and width member variables. You would want to use your helper access functions (such as Image_height and Image_width) rather than directly accessing member variables thorough the arrow operator.

subject: Remove_vertical_seam: Copying Auxiliary Image into Original Image
content: Hi, in my remove_vertical_seam function, I made an auxiliary image which holds updated values, but I need to copy all these values into the original image. I did this by setting dereferenced img equal to dereferenced auxiliary image (*img = *aux_img;).. . However, I don't understand how doing this would set all of the values in aux_img equal to img since I delete aux_img at the end of the function. . Would I have any memory issues later on since I deleted aux_img and *img is pointing to *aux_img?
i_answer: When you do "*img = *aux_img;" you're setting all of the memory values in one image equal to the other's memory values. This means the width, height, and all 3 Matrix channels get their data copied over. Because the step copies all of the data, there isn't any data that both img and aux_img are sharing. aux_img is just used as a reference to copy the data from.. . Because img and aux_img don't "share" any memory, it's safe to delete aux_img and use img as normal.

subject: P2 Test Problem

subject: What is the seam[] array?
content: I'm confused on whether we're supposed to call any of the img functions or pixels in find_minimal_vertical_seam, or just work with the cost matrix. . . . . I'm also confused on how what the seam array is. Is it an array of pointers?  And how does it relate to img?
i_answer: We're dealing with the cost matrix, which is essentially a matrix that you already made which copies the dimensions of the image and has the cost of each pixel from your energy matrix.In find minimal_vertical_seam, we are just working with the cost matrix in order to find the lowest cost path from the bottom of the matrix to the top and storing that path into the seam array.So, seam is just an array of integers, specifically column numbers for the lowest cost pixel in each row. So seam[0] = lowest cost pixel in the 0th row, and so on. This is why the specs recommend Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row for filling the seam array. Make sure you start from the bottom row as specified in the specs tho, since the first row all have the same cost. I would recommend looking at the images in the specs again if any of this is confusing!So no, you don't really work with the image until the remove vertical seam function, so u don't need to call any img functions or pixel stuff since you're just working with a matrix.

subject: Failing public test - find vertical seam
content: I'm not sure why I'm failing the tests for this function. I was trying to debug and I think that based on the cost matrix, my code seems to be giving the right output. I didn't make any changes to the processing public test file besides printing things out. Any ideas for how to fix this?.
i_answer: It looks like the first (or rather, last calculated since we are moving upwards) value in your seam matrix is wrong.. . It says "for ties, pick the leftmost" in the spec, but I think you may have misinterpreted. It means leftmost but still following the rule that you can only go up, left, or right. Since the seam in the second row was at 2, you can only choose between 1, 2, and 3 for the first row. Since it's a tie, you would pick 1.

subject: compute_energy_matrix function - assertion failure in the public tests
content: . void compute_energy_matrix(const Image* img, Matrix* energy) {.   energy->width = Image_width(img);.   energy->height = Image_height(img);.   Matrix_fill(energy, 0);. .   int maxEnergy = -2147483648;.   for (int row = 0; row < Image_height(img); row++) {.     if(row > 0 && row < (Image_height(img) - 1)) {.       for (int col = 0; col < Image_width(img); col++) {.         if(col > 0 && col < (Image_width(img) - 1)) {.           Pixel N = Image_get_pixel(img, row-1, col);.           Pixel W = Image_get_pixel(img, row, col-1);.           Pixel E = Image_get_pixel(img, row, col+1);.           Pixel S = Image_get_pixel(img, row+1, col);.           int result = squared_difference(N, S) + squared_difference(W, E);.           maxEnergy = (result > maxEnergy) ? result : maxEnergy;.         }.       }.     }.   }. .   Matrix_fill_border(energy, maxEnergy);. }. Hi! I compiled this function like the above, but it did not pass the public test. I checked it again, but I cannot find a flaw. Could you help me have a check?
i_answer: You never update the energy matrix when calculating the energy with your result variable. Also, I recommend you change your loop starting point and its terminating condition instead of the if statements you have, so think about what you should put here.. . for (int row = /*starting point*/; row < /*terminating condition*/; row++).

subject: Filling matrix array (data) with specific values
content: I did my matrix.cpp functions and am now doing tests for matrix_tests.cpp. If I wanted to have specific (distinct) values for the matrix array, how could I do that (without individually indexing every element of the array using Matrix_at). Matrix_fill wouldn't seem to work since that uses the same value for the whole array.. This is what I tried doing for a test function:. . TEST(test_website_example) {.   Matrix *mat = new Matrix; // create a Matrix in dynamic memory. .   const int width = 5;.   const int height = 3;.   Matrix_init(mat, 3, 5);.   mat->data = {1, 3, 7, 1, 3, 1, 4, 0, 13, 4, 3, -6, 2, 10, 0};. 	//didn't add rest of testing yet.   delete mat; // delete the Matrix. }. I get an error doing it like this. How could I properly do this, where I initialize the array with distinct specific values? (I didn't see a piazza post answering this and I couldn't find clear answer for directly setting values for an array of a member of a struct.)
i_answer: You should be using Matrix_at. The reason you are getting an error there is mat->data is defined to be a matrix of max size * max size length. The array you are setting it to is not of that type since it is of a different size. Another note for using matrix_at is that you want to respect the interfaces we’ve provided for you. You could make a helper function in your test file that takes in a array of values and a mat pointer. In a for loop, this function could then assign values using matrix_at. This would avoid needing to rewrite code for this test case set up.

subject: Exclusivity of column in min_value_in_row
content: Hello team! Below is my though process for computing the cost matrix... though there is an inconsistency.. . Loop through following rows (index 1 and beyond) and compute cost from previous rows. cost(r, c) = energy(r, c) + min( cost(r-1, c-1), cost(r-1, c), cost(r-1, c+1) ). -- AKA -- . cost(r, c) = energy(r, c) + Matrix_min_value_in_row(cost, r-1, c-1, c+1). But c+1 is exclusive, so it will only find the min between c-1 and c.... If I use min_value(cost, r-1, c-1, c+2) ... it will search between c-1 and c+1,. possibly indexing into the edge -- Matrix_width(cost) .. . Is my logic wrong? If not, how would I address the inconsistency?
i_answer: Your logic is right and yes it will access out of bounds if that is all you did. Maybe if statements will help here and your function behaves differently when it’s on column 0 and column width, and it’s what you described here for everything else.

subject: Seg faults when testing functions that call Matrix_at
content: I can successfully test matrix functions when accessing data member directly; however, any time I test a function that calls Matrix_at (e.g matrix_fill, matrix_print, etc), I run into seg faults. Has anyone experienced something similar?
i_answer: I recommend you run these problematic tests under your debugger, so you can see exactly which line the segmentation fault is occurring on. It's possible your index calculation in Matrix_at() is incorrect, and thus you're returning a pointer to invalid memory. It's also possible your index calculation is correct, but you are returning a pointer to an object that no longer exists after Matrix_at() returns (such as a local variable), rather than a pointer to an integer in the Matrix's data array. There are many possible causes for your seg fault; I recommend you use your debugger and the address sanitizer like you did in Lab 3 to investigate.

That 6/10 means we ran your Matrix tests against our own buggy Matrix implementations, and your tests exposed enough bugs to earn 6 points. It's a good sign that you're passing the Matrix public tests on the autograder, along with your own local tests. Right now, your Matrix tests are testing two types of matrices; I recommend you expand your test suite to test more types of Matrices, along with more edge cases for each Matrix function.

subject: resize() segmentation fault
content: I was able to pass all of the make test tests via terminal.. . But when I used an online jpg to ppm convertor and tried to resize the image of some of my friends I got an segmentation fault :/. . . Does this mean that there's something wrong with my program, or the ppm file?
i_answer: Is the image larger than 500x500? If so, the image won't be able to fit into the data arrays we allocate for the red/green/blue Matrix channels, since MAX_MATRIX_WIDTH and MAX_MATRIX_HEIGHT are both 500. Just for fun, you can try making these constants larger than 500, but depending on how much memory you have available, your resize program may struggle with images much larger than 500x500...

subject: Can't write our own helper functions for the matrix module?
content: As I am completing the Matrix module and implementing functions for matrix.cpp, I wanted to write a couple new functions that weren't defined by the project. (Specifically I wanted an int* Matrix_at(Matrix* mat, int i) to allow me to get data from the matrix by index rather than by row and col, like the functions suggested.) I wrote this function (and even duplicated it, one copy for const and one for normal), and added the stub for it to the matrix.h file and all of my tests run fine. However, when submitting to the autograder, it can't find those function stubs since I don't submit my own matrix.h to the autograder, meaning it can't know ahead of time that those functions will be used. Is this in error? Am I meant to just write the function stubs at the top of all the other programs right after the #include "matrix.h"? This seems contrary to the course which has always encouraged the creation of your own helper functions, but now isn't giving me all of the tools to do so by not allowing me to submit my own matrix.h. Any clarification here would be greatly appreciated.
i_answer: On the autograder, we compile your .cpp files against unmodified versions of Matrix.h and Image.h. You can add helper functions to your .cpp files, but if you try to reference a helper function from another .cpp file (under the assumption that it is defined in a header file you're including), your code will fail to compile on the autograder with a linker error, since we won't be able to find that function in any of our versions of the header files.. . You can still write helper functions at the top of your .cpp files, but you can only use those helper functions within that file since you cannot submit your own header files.

subject: Testing matrix_row and matrix_column
content: When we test our matrix_row and matrix_column functions in our terminal, it works and the tests pass. However, when we submit to the autograder, it says that there is a False Positive error which I have attached to this comment. I was wondering if I could get clarification to why this might be happening.
i_answer: The mutation tests use both buggy and working code to test your tests. It’s supposed to give a positive result when there is buggy code and a negative result when there isn’t anything wrong. It seems like your code is giving positive results for code that is working. This could mean your functions aren’t working correctly and that both your tests and functions are slightly off, or maybe it could mean your tests don’t quite work with edge cases. In any case, you probably want to check both the test and your function implementation

subject: memory leak
content: hello I am going through all my code to find my memory leak that's displayed on autograder, all my new operators have delete, however for the array I make a dynamically stored one, but when I try to delete it I get an error, any suggestions....
i_answer: you have to delete your dynamically allocated seam array using the delete[] operator, so . . delete[] seam; . The reason that it's delete[] vs. delete is that you dynamically allocated an array, so all the elements will be dynamic. delete[] makes sure all of them get deleted.

subject: Inconsistency in how Column Indices are being Used
content: In the function Matrix_at(), the Requires has "0 <= column && column < Matrix_width(mat), " which means that the column input is from 0 to width - 1; however, in other functions (Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row() and Matrix_min_value_in_row()), the Requires has "0 <= column_start && column_end <= Matrix_width(mat), " which means that the column input is from 0 to width.. Is there any reason for this inconsistency? I would think that indexing consistently would be less confusing.
i_answer: You should be zero indexing, but the Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row is exclusive for it's upper bound.

subject: row and column functions

i_answer: The functions should just return the row or column numbers. For example, if ptr is a pointer to an element in the third row and second column of the matrix, then Matrix_row(mat, ptr) would return 3 and Matrix_col(mat, ptr) would return 2..

subject: Image_init(img, width, height) is very slow
content: For processing_tests.cpp, my code breezes past the tests for dog.ppm and crabster.ppm, though horses.ppm takes an absurdly long amount of time. I've narrowed down the problem to the Image_init function: for it to run once takes around 3 minutes for horses.ppm. The inefficiency makes sense, as it's initializing a matrix for ever color channel for every pixel in the image (over 407k matrices), but is there a way to run Image_init(img, width, height) without it having to call Matrix_init() so many times, or just generally a way to make it less demanding?
i_answer: Also, to improve efficiency, remember that you don't have to set a Matrix to contain all 0s on Matrix_init().. . However, the point of our projects is not micro-optimizations like this (unless it gets necessary). The student's answer is what you have to focus on first.

subject: calling matrix_at()
content: so there are two matrix_at() functions - one returns a const int* and one returns an int*. i went to office hours and the IA/GSI said that it's a compiler decision between which function to use. does that mean that calling both function will be the same or is there a different way to call each function?
i_answer: Notice that the parameters passed into the two functions are different. For the one that returns const int*, you are passing a const Matrix*. . const int* Matrix_at(const Matrix* mat, int row, int column);. If you pass in a pointer to a const Matrix (const Matrix* mat), then the compiler will understand that you are trying to use this function that returns a const int*. . whereas,. . If you pass in a pointer to a Matrix (Matrix* mat), then it will understand you are trying to call the function that returns int*

subject: image_set_pixel implementation
content: For the Image_set_pixel function, I am calling the Matrix_at function and passing in img-> red_channel as the first parameter (type *mat). However img-> red_channel is a matrix and not a pointer to a matrix. How would I change this to pass in a pointer to the red channel matrix?
i_answer: In general, if you want to pass a pointer to a non-pointer value, you can get the memory address of that value with the & symbol.For example, if I understand your question correctly, a pointer to the matrix of the red channel could be. . Matrix* red_mat = &(img->red_channel);

subject: Matrix_row function warning
content: (This post can only be seen by instructors). . For the Matrix_row function, I wrote like this bc I wanted to use Pointer Arithmetic, but there is a warning saying it loses integer precision. Is this normal?.
i_answer: Yes this is normal. . . Technically since pointers are stored as 8-byte integers under the hood, and the "diff" variable you declared is only 4-bytes, it is possible that the difference between two 8-byte numbers could be larger than what a 4-byte integer can store. That is why the compiler is recommending using a long, which is an 8-byte integer.

subject: Second image_init RGB values
content: I'm confused on what the second Image_Init function (the one with istream is as a parameter) needs to do with the pixels. If it's supposed to set the individual pixels based on the information from the istream, how does that differ from set_Pixel?. . So far I've initialized the Matrix structs for each color channel (red, green, and blue). I then have a nested loop that  reads in the pixel values for each color channel by iterating through the rows and columns of the image, and I'm guessing I have to use matrix_at or matrix_fill somehow, but I'm confused on what I'm supposed to do with them and what to do inside this loop generally.. . Also, am I supposed to read in three values at a time?
i_answer: This image init function is to read in ppm images. Look at dog.ppm in your starter files for an example of what it should be. It differs from set pixel in that the init function reads everything that is given and the set pixel function only changes the value of one pixel in the whole image. . . In your loops, you basically need to change the rgb matrices to match the values that are given. Note that this is an init function, and you would probably need to set width and height of the image and use Matrix init for the rgb matrices.. . And lastly, yes. Apart from the header which has P3, width, height, and max intensity, everything is 3 values at a time. Note that you don’t need to care about P3 and max intensity since I believe the spec says you’re basically guaranteed these will be the same values.

subject: Grading of coding style
content: Hello,. . Unfortunately, I didn't get any points on Autograder's style grading, and I want to ask for some clarification on style guidelines.. . 1. Is there any way Autograder can let me know which lines of code violate the style guidelines?. . 2. I used the code formatting command on VSCode (shift + option + f), but this doesn't help me get any points on style checks. . . 3. Is the style guideline available on EECS 280 course website?. . 4. Within how many characters should I write in a line? In my project, when a line is likely to be too long, I simply split it into two parts and put one part down to a new line. But I still lost all points on this criterion;. . 5. Within how many lines should my function has? Some of my functions have 40 lines of code, and are they "long functions?". . 6. I don't have any deep nesting code in my project. The max amount of loops of a function I implemented was 2 (double for loop). However, I lost all points on this criterion. . . 7. Within how many parameters should a function take? All functions I have take a reasonable amount of parameters (within 4), except Assert_Equal(). For ASSERT_EQUAL, it takes two arguments, but one argument (let's say, Matrix_in_value_in_row()) takes 4 arguments. Is that the reason I lost points on this guideline?. . 8. I'm not sure why I got the problem of "code duplication." I wrote some similar test cases in Matrix_test.cpp. Instead of testing each function in matrix.cpp in one testing function, I tested each possible shape of matrices. As a result, the major difference between each testing function I wrote in matrix_test.cpp is the matrix I constructed at the beginning. Except for this, I tested the same functions. Is this considered "duplication?". . I am sorry to write a lot of words but I am very frustrated for losing all points on styling after spending days coding. Also, since I am a new transfer student, I am not sure if UM has specific coding style guidelines. I would appreciate if you can give me some help. Thank you!. . Best,. Bowen. .
i_answer: Per @64, please make sure you have your uniqname in your piazza handler so we can look up your submission. . . Your image.cpp and resize.cpp did not compile. Hence you will not pass the style checks. I would make sure that all files compile first when trying to check for style. You can check if your code adheres to our style guide by running this command in your project directory.. . make style. . . Is there any way Autograder can let me know which lines of code violate the style guidelines?. . Yes, but I think since not all of your files compiled correctly, the style check did not run.. . . I used the code formatting command on VSCode (shift + option + f), but this doesn't help me get any points on style checks. . . Some code formatters work, and some don't. I personally think VScode formatting is a mess, so I don't think it will be a big help. If you commit to writing clean code when you start coding, and try to fix it as soon as you notice it, it'll make it easier for you to pass style checks. Check our C++ style guide on how to make sure you write clean code.. . . Is the style guideline available on EECS 280 course website?. . Yes, please check EECS 280 style checking for a detailed way to generate style reports. It will tell you what lines are violating style checks. . . . Within how many characters should I write in a line? In my project, when a line is likely to be too long, I simply split it into two parts and put one part down to a new line. But I still lost all points on this criterion;. . Less than 90 characters. . . Within how many lines should my function has? Some of my functions have 40 lines of code, and are they "long functions?". . Most of the functions in this project are relatively short. If you have 40-line functions, I think you are overthinking some things!. . . I don't have any deep nesting code in my project. The max amount of loops of a function I implemented was 2 (double for loop). However, I lost all points on this criterion. . . If your code doesn't compile, you won't get the points for style.. . . Within how many parameters should a function take? All functions I have take a reasonable amount of parameters (within 4), except Assert_Equal(). For ASSERT_EQUAL, it takes two arguments, but one argument (let's say, Matrix_in_value_in_row()) takes 4 arguments. Is that the reason I lost points on this guideline?. . you should be good here. most of functions are provided by us and seems like you don't have functions with more than 4 parameters.. . . I'm not sure why I got the problem of "code duplication." I wrote some similar test cases in Matrix_test.cpp. Instead of testing each function in matrix.cpp in one testing function, I tested each possible shape of matrices. As a result, the major difference between each testing function I wrote in matrix_test.cpp is the matrix I constructed at the beginning. Except for this, I tested the same functions. Is this considered "duplication?". . Code duplication means you have the exact same lines of code more than once. Basically copy + pasting the same code..

subject: Weird letters on my files

subject: Testing Guidelines
content: Do you recommend we test each function individually? Or can we test multiple functions together such as in Matrix_public_test?
i_answer: I recommend you have one test for each function you are testing. Also, remember that you can only submit 50 tests.. . For instance, for testing Matrix_max(), I would create a function such as this:. . TEST(test_Matrix_max). {. 	// test cases here. 	// try different matrices with different sizes and values. }

subject: Segmentation Fault when running processing_public_tests.exe
content: Everytime I run ./processing_public_tests.exe, it says I get a segmentation error. What does this mean?
i_answer: It probably means that you are indexing out of bounds. It would be difficult for us to know exactly what is happening, so I suggest using the debugger and setting breakpoints. Try to see before what line the segmentation fault happens and debug from there.Office hours can help for a more thorough investigation of the bug if you are not able to find it by debugging.

subject: Matrix_tests - missing one mutation test
content: Hi! I have spent all day trying to figure out why I am missing one mutation test for Matrix tests. According to the autograder I have found 9/10 buggy implementations, but I really am not sure what I could be missing. I feel that I wrote very exhaustive tests for all the functions and edge cases. If anyone could point me in the right direction (i.e., what function I am not testing enough) I would really appreciate it since I am super stuck on this.. . ![image.png](/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&prefix=paste%2Flcij6xuzlgl373%2F26a2e46765fc992ba41b653dd924baa471239f325fa332c2dad03ad945787e74%2Fimage.png)
i_answer: My strategy for finding bugs for points is to always check for what assumptions have the public tests we've given have made, but the spec doesn't state. Ex. for p1, all the input was sorted in our public test cases, but the spec didn't make explicit mention that you were guaranteed input would be sorted.

subject: matrix col and matrix row
content: Are we assuming that each indexes in the matrix stores 4 bytes of memory? When I tried to find the difference between the element and the beginning to find the index it converted the pointers to a long type, which became a really big number. I saw on the comments that we should not trust the public test? I just want to clarify does that mean the test is written incorrectly?
i_answer: . we should not trust the public test? I just want to clarify does that mean the test is written incorrectly?. . The public test is written correctly. However, it is not a thorough test of your implementation (hence why you need to write your own test cases). It tests some basic stuff and helps you to make sure your code compiles.. . . Are we assuming that each indexes in the matrix stores 4 bytes of memory? When I tried to find the difference between the element and the beginning to find the index it converted the pointers to a long type. . I suggest reviewing this week's lab on pointer arithmetics for this issue.

subject: Matrix UB Test Memory Leak Error
content: I keep getting this error for the Matrix UB tests on the autograder. I'm pretty sure that in my test file every matrix I create is deleted at the end of the function.I would really appreciate if someone could help me fix this issue
i_answer: Converting to private since we are discussing code specifics. Because you are failing your assertion at line 48 in matrix.cpp, the delete you have later in the function never executes. If you pass that assertion, your delete will run and you won't have a memory leak.

subject: Assertion Confusion - Confusing Assertion in Processing Part
content: Hi! When I was building functions, I felt greatly confused with several functions' assertation explanations in different parts. I list them below about the Processing part:. . energy points to a Matrix / cost points to a Matrix (No idea about the address of a Matrix Structure here.)seam points to an array(How to detect the address range of the array? Do you wanna us to check the address that the pointer points to is within the address range of the array?)the size of seam is >= Matrix_height(cost) / the size of seam is == Image_height(img) (Without any input info about the seam array size, we can never know the size of the seam array. C++ Array cannot be measured with built-in functions.). . . . . . . . . Could you offer a detailed official explanation here for all of these confusing assertions in Processing.cpp? I have no questions about pointers and I/O stream definition. Much appreciated.. . . . . . . .
i_answer: Essentially, you will get a valid data passed into your function. I.E we won't pass in a bad ppm file, or a null pointer into your function. . . Some things will be more difficult to assert than others. You don't have to assert every requires we have in the RME. If something seems fairly easy to assert, feel free to do so, but it isn't required.

subject: Assertion Confusion - Confusing Assertion in Image Part
content: Hi! When I was building functions, I felt greatly confused with several functions' assertation explanations in different parts. I list them below about the Image part:. . img points to an Image(No idea about the address of an Image Structure here.)img points to a valid Image(What defines a valid Image?)img points to an Image contains an image in PPM format without comments (any kind of whitespace is ok)(How to detect the target one is an image containing PPM?). . . . . . . Could you offer a detailed official explanation here for all of these confusing assertions in Image.cpp? I have no questions about pointers and I/O stream definition. Much appreciated.. . . . . . . .
i_answer: Essentially, you will get a valid data passed into your function. I.E we won't pass in a bad ppm file, or a null pointer into your function. . . Some things will be more difficult to assert than others. You don't have to assert every requires we have in the RME. If something seems fairly easy to assert, feel free to do so, but it isn't required.

subject: Assertion Confusion - Confusing Assertion in Matrix Part
content: Hi! When I was building functions, I felt greatly confused with several functions' assertation explanations in different parts. I list them below about the Matrix part:. . mat points to a Matrix(No idea about the address of a Matrix here.)mat points to an valid Matrix(What defines a valid Matrix?)ptr points to an element in the Matrix(Does this mean the address this pointer points to needs to be within the address range of the Matrix data array?). Could you offer a detailed official explanation here for all of these confusing assertions in Matrix.cpp? I have no questions about pointers and I/O stream definition.Much appreciated..
i_answer: > `mat` points to a Matrix. . This just means that `mat` is a pointer to a `Matrix` instance -- that is, it has the type `Matrix *`. In this project, you will generally create `Matrix` instances on the *heap* (will be explained in a later lecture) using the `new` keyword (this is all you need to know for now). Basically, a matrix, with $$500 \times 500$$ `int`s in it, is ***wayyy*** too big to store in the stack frame for any function, so we can instead use the `new` keyword to create it, which just makes it "somewhere else" in memory and returns a pointer to that "somewhere else" location which we store as our pointer, `mat`. For example:. ```cpp. Matrix *mat = new Matrix;. ```. . > `mat` points to a valid `Matrix`. . This just means the `Matrix`-pointer has been allocated using `new` and then initialized using the `Matrix_init()` function and thus has valid height/width properties.. . ```cpp. Matrix *mat = new Matrix;. Matrix_init(mat);. // mat now points to a valid Matrix!. ```. . > `ptr` points to an element in the `Matrix`. >. > Does this mean the address this pointer points to needs to be within the address range of the `Matrix->data` array?. >. Yes.

subject: Processing.cpp Failing Horses
content: Hi, . . I am failing horses seam carve, and it says there is a corrupt value.  How can I go about fixing this error?.
i_answer: I would look into seeing if you're accessing a value after calling delete. Walking through this test case with the debugger should help you find it.

subject: Image_init (istream) Unsure how to finish the function
content: . I'm trying to write the image init function and I'm pretty confused how to use is<<. I've tried reading other piazza questions and the project spec but I'm still confused. How should I get rid of the P3 term? And is using a while loop the right way to get the pixel colors? I just don't know how to use istream to store the colors.
i_answer: Using a `while` loop here is a good idea. And, yes, you can read `P3` into a random variable as you won't be needing it later. Regarding reading pixels into your image, are there any functions that you've written in `image.cpp` that would allow you to store the pixels into an image?

subject: Do I need to initialize the new image copied over in remove_vertical_seam()?
content: Title!
i_answer: You will probably want to initialize a new image, I'm not sure how else you could do this. Although remember you should also delete any memory you are no longer using.

subject: UB check failure allocator/deallocator mismatch
content: I ran into this error message from the autograder and I don't understand what it means. My code passes all of the public tests when I run them from the terminal.
i_answer: At some point you allocate an array with new. When you free it you are using "delete", however you should use "delete[]".

subject: Qs about test cases
content: For project 2, what are the specific requirements for Matrix_tests.cpp and Image_tests.cpp? Do we need to write test cases for each of the function? If so, how many? Thank you!
i_answer: There is no set number of test cases you need to write or for how many functions you'll need to write test cases. However, I would suggest writing test cases for all your functions as it not only good practice, but will help you expose more bugs for AG points.

subject: dog.ppm wrong formatting
content: . I was going to test the dog.ppm file but noticed that the rows do not match the rows indicated above. Is this supposed to be like an edge case we should check for or is it simply wrong?
i_answer: What do you mean by "the rows do not match the rows indicated above"? If you mean that the pixel values are not displayed in a 5x5, whitespaces/new lines in the input file do not matter. For example, you could have all the pixel values on one line. If you're reading in the pixel values correctly using cin, you shouldn't have to worry about doing anything extra for whitespace.

subject: Processing.cpp Remove_Seam Question
content: Never mind, Please resolve this. I dereferenced the pointers and it worked.. . . Hi, I just had a question on how to set the original image to the image with the seams removed?. . I was using. .   img = new_img;  // replace.   delete new_img; // delete the Image. . . But it seems that once new_img is deleted, img just reverts back to its original data and values.
i_answer: resolved

subject: Trouble with git push -u origin main
content: When going through the version control tutorial, I have come across the following problem: . . . . Does anyone have an idea as to how to fix this?
i_answer: I would try to run git remote and make sure the link matches that of your repository. If it does, make sure you have your credentials set up on git and make sure to set up your ssh key if you haven't already (there are good GitHub tutorials on how to do this).

subject: make Error
content: Whenever I run make and then some filename, I keep getting the error "Nothing to be done for `filename'." How do I fix this?
i_answer: It could be that you're not in the right directory, or that you're accidentally trying to make a cpp file rather than an exe file. Could you give an example of a file that gives that error message?

subject: Check respecting Matrix interface in student tests
content: Hi, I'm getting an error in the autograder I do not know how to fix. . EECS280_p2_error1.png. The error is in "Check respecting Matrix interface in student tests," saying "struct Matrix has no member named data." There are error messages for my code, but also in the code that was included in the starter files (void test_fill_basic()). What can I do to fix this?. . If needed, my uniqname is ealcott. Thank you!
i_answer: You can directly access a Matrix's member variables in the Matrix.cpp class, but you can't access them outside (ie. in Matrix_tests.cpp).

subject: remove_vertical_seam function - copying over edited image to original
content: I'm a little confused on how to copy over the auxiliary image to the original image -- I understand the concept of updating the img pointer to point to a new value but I'm not sure how to go about doing it. My original thought was to create a pointer to each element in my image copy and set the pointer to the corresponding row and column in the original image equal to that. However, there isn't an image analog for Matrix_at so I wasn't sure what to use
i_answer: Try not to overthink it. Let `aux` be a pointer to the newly created image, and suppose `img` is a pointer to the old image. Then you can access the actual image objects for each by dereferencing each. Then it's just a matter of setting the dereferenced old image to the dereferenced new image.

processing.cpp: In function ‘void seam_carve_width(Image*, int)’:. processing.cpp:275:28: error: ‘struct Image’ has no member named ‘height’.   275 |   Matrix_init(energy, img->height, img->width);.       |                            ^~~~~~. processing.cpp:275:41: error: ‘struct Image’ has no member named ‘width’.   275 |   Matrix_init(energy, img->height, img->width);.       |                                         ^~~~~. processing.cpp:276:26: error: ‘struct Image’ has no member named ‘height’.   276 |   Matrix_init(cost, img->height, img->width);.       |                          ^~~~~~. processing.cpp:276:39: error: ‘struct Image’ has no member named ‘width’.   276 |   Matrix_init(cost, img->height, img->width);.       |                                       ^~~~~. processing.cpp:278:14: error: ‘struct Image’ has no member named ‘width’.   278 |   while(img->width!=newWidth){.       |              ^~~~~. make: *** [public.mk:112: processing_respect_interfaces.o] Error 1
i_answer: You should not be directly accessing data member variables of a struct outside their respective files. This means that for Image, you should only ever do `img->width` and `img->height` when you're in `Image.cpp`. Outside of that, you should only use `Image_width` and `Image_height`. This relates to "respecting the interface" from lecture.

subject: processing.cpp compute_energy_matrix - Confusion on what "N/S and W/E neighbors" means
content: The spec says that "The energy of X is the sum of the squared differences between its N/S and E/W neighbors", I was confused on what values exactly we're taking the squared differences of. Are we looking at the neighbors of X in the energy matrix and taking the energy values of its neighbors to compute the energy of each pixel? If so, wouldn't that just give zero, since we initialized the energy matrix to be filled with zeros?
i_answer: I'd say your first thought sounds reasonable. Try to go through the graph in the specification of this project again, and you should think of no matter where is the pixel (except at the border), there is a universal way to express the location of its neighbors (has something to do with row and column number associated with the location of X - which is the central pixel). . Also, for your last question, I think you only initialize the energy matrix to be zero, but you should use the value of pixels in your image to compute the energy for each pixel which shouldn't be zero.

subject: stuck at resize.cpp
content: Hi, I have two issues on resize.cpp. . 1 Do we need to include any other files in resize except project ID?. . 2 After reading from command (i.e. ./resize.exe horses.ppm horses_400x250.ppm 400 250) I now get two strings and two(or one) integers.. . i_answer: Well you only need the project UID as a comment and include all the other libraries you need. I don’t think you include files in your resize. Its supposed to be able to take in inputs from the command line to resize accordingly.. . For your second question, something seems wrong there. Your program should be able to open files, give any necessary error outputs, and output files, all from the command line inputs.. . Yes you should open an ifstream, and no it won’t give you an image pointer. It gives you a ifstream in the form of ppm format file, so you should be using one of the functions you previously wrote (i’m assuming you did matrix, image and processing) to read in this ppm file. Also you probably want to create and destroy an image struct somewhere

subject: matrix_init function, unused data
content: When I was implementing matrix_int func, I initialized all unused elements to 0, which is not required by the spec. Would auto grader deduct points on this, since my test cases assume that the initialized elements are all 0.
i_answer: While I don't think that the public tests will check any element within the matrix right after init is called, I believe there is no reason to fill unused elements to 0. I think it is expected that the matrix will not be checked until it is populated, either with file input, a call to fill, or having each individual element be changed.

subject: Matrix_max Traversal by pointer versus traversal by int
content: I am currently writing my matrix_max function and I am not sure whether to use traversal by pointer or not. What is a good way to decipher this? Thank you!
i_answer: I believe that traversal by both pointer and index is completely valid for this finding this function. You are just returning the maximum value, so neither pointer nor index would provide any significant efficiency increase or lead to significantly cleaner code. You should just use whichever one you feel more comfortable with or feels more intuitive for this specific problem.

subject: Public Image test using 'poorly behaved PPM format'
content: Is there any reason that the image_init(istream) gives us poorly behaved PPM input? Is our code expected to work with faulty PPM format? This is really confusing why the public tests use faulty PPM formatting...
i_answer: From the spec, "Because we may be reading in images generated from programs that don’t use whitespace in the same way that we do, the Image_init function must accommodate any kind of whitespace used to separate elements of the PPM format (if you use C++ style I/O with >>, this should be no problem).". In public tests, you may see sometimes we use tabs instead of spaces to separate two numbers, and this is allowed. This is a "poorly behaved" input, but not faulty. As the spec said, if you use >>, this should already be handled for you.

subject: Image_init/Image_print Image_public_test.exe errors
content: I'm currently debugging my Image_init and Image_print functions in Image.cpp for P2 and running the Image_public_test.exe to try and find my errors. Currently, I am failing all of the tests, and when it prints out my version in the test this is what shows:. . . I'm really confused what the spacing and ? and != are in my output. Nowhere in my code or input do I have these values so I'm really unsure as to why they are printing. . . I have already tried:. - using different variations of for and while loops to read in and print the different color hex values. - reference the Pixel struct to store and print the color hex values. - reference the img->red_channel.data etc. to store values when reading them in. . Not really sure how else to attempt this problem or determine where the error is coming from
i_answer: != shows you the difference between your actual output and the expected correct output.. You may want to check that you successfully initialized your image. Only after that, you may check if your print function works since if your image is "empty", nothing would be printed out.. For initialization, you may want to use other functions you implemented in image.cpp to avoid duplicate code. To be more specific, initializing an image with istream includes set up each pixel in this image. From the spec, "To read and write individual Pixels in an Image, use the Image_get_pixel and Image_set_pixel functions, respectively.". Also you may want to read the "Respect the interfaces!" of our spec. For example, if you want to access data from image, consider Matrix_at() instead of directly using mat->data.

subject: compiler error, partner compile issues
content: Hi, my partner started writing some of the functions for matrix.cpp in her files on xcode. She hasn't been able to set up github yet which she is working on. But when I paste her code into my file it won't compile but she is able to compile it on her end. There is just one error that says. Matrix.cpp:15:55: error: suggest braces around initialization of subobject [-Werror,-Wmissing-braces]    mat1 = {mat1.width = width, mat1.height = height, mat1.data[width * height]};. . Here is an image showing the code and the compiler error. . Thank you for your help, Gigi Celi. .
i_answer: Thanks for your question! If you look at matrix.h, you'll see that data[MAX_MATRIX_WIDTH * MAX_MATRIX_HEIGHT] is already initialized as a member variable of the matrix struct. This means whenever you create a Matrix object it will automatically have a data array initialized, so you don't need to redeclare it. In matrix_init, you should just set mat->height and mat->width to the inputted values.. . The error is valid, because you shouldn't be initializing the data array like this. I'm not sure why it did not appear on your partner's compiler.

subject: Image_init throwing an error
content: Hi, I'm running into the following error when trying to use the format:. . . . I'm basically doing: is >> Matrix_at(&img->green_channel, r, c) and it outputs this error.
i_answer: Matrix_at() returns a pointer to an integer in the Matrix. I'm assuming you're reading an integer in from the input stream. You cannot set the pointer returned by Matrix_at() to the next integer read in, but can you use this pointer to set the integer it points to? Think about the operators we use with pointers.

subject: Help with matrix_at function
content: . int* Matrix_at(Matrix* mat, int row, int column) {. int index;. int width= mat -> width;. index = row * (width) + column; // we turn a 2-D matrix into a 1-D array through this equation.. int *ptr = mat[index]; // Question. return *ptr;. assert(false);. . . This is my code. I want to point to the value of the index in the array but am having trouble referring to it. mat [index] is underlined with an error saying "no suitable conversion function from "Matrix" to "int *" exists". Am I on the right track with my code and how do I refer to the value of the index I calculate.. Thanks
i_answer: mat is a pointer to a Matrix; it looks like you want to access that Matrix's underlying data array. You can access data the same way you access the Matrix's width in your Matrix_at() implementation (using the mat pointer and the arrow operator); then, you can index into data using the [] operator.. . Also, say you have an integer array called arr. The operation "arr[index]" will return the integer at that index, not a pointer to that element. If you want to get a pointer to the element in arr at index, is there another operator that can help you here? Or alternatively, can you exploit the fact that arr can decay into a pointer to its first element, and then perform some pointer arithmetic?

subject: Using red_channel, blue_channel, green_channel in Image_init
content: I'm confused on why red_channel, blue_channel, and green_channel are matrices and what they represent. . . I'm also looking at the RME for both the Matrix_init functions and I'm confused on how I'm supposed to use red_channel, blue_channel, and green_channel in these functions.
i_answer: The red, green and blue channels represent the color value for each pixel on the screen. They are stored as matrices as a matrix is a 2d grid of numbers, as that is a convenient way to represent your 2d grid of pixels. You would use your matrix functions, such as matrix init, to alter your color channels to do whatever the image RME tells you to do.

subject: specs requirements questions
content: in the DOs section in the specs for project 2, it says to use c-style strings when processing command line arguments and use c++ style strings when working with streams and file I/O? i know what c-style and c++ style string are, but i'm not sure how to apply it to each of the categories.
i_answer: C style strings are char arrays, whereas C++ style strings (std::string).. . If you look at the parameters for the main method, you'll notice that they are int argc and char *argv[]. The first parameter indicates the number of arguments, and the second one is an array of the arguments, C style strings. This is why the project spec says to use C style strings for command line inputs, and C++ style strings everywhere else.. . If you are still confused, I suggest taking a look at the notes on strings, which explains what C style and C++ style strings are and how they work. The Command Line Arguments section and the File I/O section are very useful.

subject: Matrix_fill data member
content: Is it fine if we access the data member variable directly to assign the value to each element in Matrix_fill? Or do we have to use other functions?
i_answer: No function other than Matrix_row, Matrix_column, and the two versions of Matrix_at should access the data member directly

subject: do we use new/delete in resize.cpp?
content: Are we required to use new/delete in resize.cpp or we can but not required?. . Thanks!
i_answer: Any time you need to declare an image or matrix object, you should declare it dynamically using new/delete. If you find that this is required in resize.cpp, you should use new/delete.

subject: Error when running Image_public_test
content: Running test: test_image_basicImage_public_test.exe: Matrix.cpp:82: int* Matrix_at(Matrix*, int, int): Assertion `0 <= row && row < Matrix_height(mat)' failed.Aborted. . I am getting the following failed assertion when running Image_public_test.exe but there are no errors when running Matrix_public_test.exe or Matrix_tests.exe. Does this mean that there is something wrong with my implementation of Matrix_at or something wrong with a function Image.cpp?
i_answer: The assertion error suggests that, in your Image class, you’re trying to access a matrix in a row that is out of the bounds of your matrix.For example, if your matrix has 5 rows, you might be trying to access row 7. Most likely, this is an issue with your Image class.To fix this, one suggestion is to use the Debugger in your IDE or Text Editor, so you can “step through” your code and see where the faulty value is being passed.

subject: Matrix_width and Matrix_height - accessing width and height
content: . . . . My partner and I are working on the width and height functions in matrix.cpp, and we are wondering why we cannot access the width and height member variables of the Matrix class through the dot operator. Every time we try to return width, it says the variable is undefined when we use the dot operator, and we are unsure how else to access the variable. . . . . . . .
i_answer: you should use the ->  (so mat->width) operator since you are trying to access a pointer to a matrix. This is briefly covered in lecture from monday there is a way to use the dot operator but you must de reference the matrix first and then use the dot operator like so (*mat).width

subject: seam_carve_width function - implementation takes 90+ minutes to run
content: Dear EECS 280 Staff,. . I am having trouble with the seam_carve_width function. My current implementation seems to work, although it takes about 1h30m to run the public test, which will obviously not pass autograder. I know using a while loop in my implementation is sub-optimal right now, do you have any suggestions on how to re-write it so it can be sped up? I have listed the code below.. . . void seam_carve_width(Image *img, int newWidth) {.   Matrix *energy=new Matrix();.   Matrix *cost=new Matrix();.   int seam[MAX_MATRIX_HEIGHT];. .   while(img->width!=newWidth){.     Matrix_init(energy, img->height, img->width);.     Matrix_init(cost, img->height, img->width);. .     compute_energy_matrix(img, energy);.     compute_vertical_cost_matrix(energy, cost);.     find_minimal_vertical_seam(cost, seam);.     remove_vertical_seam(img, seam);.   }. .   delete energy;.   delete cost;. . }. . Thank you for your help!. Alvin Tuo
i_answer: I don't think the issue is in this function. It's most likely in some Matrix/Image function, or you're calling a function an excessive number of times. It'd help to look through all your files in office hours.. . You can also run perf to find out where your code is taking the longest: https://eecs280staff.github.io/p2-cv/perf.html

subject: Autograder Resize Public Test exit status 0
content: On the autograder for project 2, both "Resize Public Test" I get the point but when I go to the run part of it, it says my exit status is 255 when it should be 0. I don't get any errors when I run it, so why is my exit status not 0?
i_answer: It looks like you are returning -1 at the end of your main function in resize. Legal values for exit codes are between 0 - 255. You want to switch that to return 0 to signal a successful exit. . . If you're interested, here's a stack overflow post that explains it in depth. . https://stackoverflow.com/questions/31626445/c-programs-return-int-type-so-why-does-return-1-return-255. . . PS: you should edit your piazza username to have your uniqname; it makes it a lot easier for us to take a look at your autograder output

subject: Matrix_row and Matrix_column pointer arithmetic help
content: . So far I've printed out what my pointers are pointing to and the difference between them. I'm getting 25 as my distance between ptr and the first element of data but for Matrix_public_tests.cpp this is not what the test case should result with. I think it might be syntax but I don't know what is incorrect. Any help with what is wrong would be great.
i_answer: You should examine the logic you have on line 68 of your Matrix_row function and think about if the modulo operator yields the value you are looking for. Remember, the logic to find an element's row and an element's column will be different. It helps to draw out the data array to figure out what operations you can do to get to the value you are looking for.

subject: How to access the individual columns/rows
content: I am having a hard time when it comes to matrix_column and matrix_row. I understand that in implementation, Matrix holds all the data in a one-dimensional array, so how am I supposed to adequately split that array up and access each separate row or column. Am I supposed to create new arrays? I’m very lost and don’t know where to even start and would love any pointers. I’m trying to write my code to where I can take the data from mat and split it up by their column/row in order to then iterate through and find where the given element lies. Is this the correct thought process?
i_answer: As the spec mentions, there's no need to use loops for these functions, and doing so will make your code run quite slow.The better approach is to use pointer arithmetic: if you can somehow find the current index of the pointer within the Matrix's data, you can then use the modulo and division operations to determine the row and column the pointer is currently at within the Matrix's data.To find the index that the pointer is currently at, you just need to subtract the location of the pointer "ptr" (the one pointing at a cell in the Matrix's data) in memory and the location of the the beginning of the Matrix's data in memory.Hopefully this sets you on the right track!

subject: Image_print name of image @ beginning of stream
content: I'm having some difficulty determining how to print the name of the image at the beginning of your stream for Image_print. Since the name of the image is not a variable stored in the Image struct, how would we know what to print? Is there a way to print the name of a struct in C++?
i_answer: I don't believe you have to print the name of the image at the beginning, only the _type_ of PPM image. The first line of the output will always be "P3" in our case, which indicates that the format is Plain PPM.

subject: How many test cases?
content: How many test cases should we have per function? Is it okay if we only have one for some of the simpler functions?
i_answer: There's no limit / minimum required test cases. Just try to catch as many bugs as possible, you can even include multiple asserts in one test case.

subject: seam_carve_width not working
content: Hi,. . I keep running into issues relating to variable array size in regards to the seam array. Please take a look at the code and let me know me know what I can change.. . . void seam_carve_width(Image *img, int newWidth) {.   const int height=Image_height(img);.   .   for(int i=0;i<img->width-newWidth;i++){.     Matrix *energy=new Matrix();.     Matrix_init(energy,img->width-i,img->height);.     compute_energy_matrix(img, energy);.     Matrix *cost=new Matrix();.     Matrix_init(cost, img->width-i,img->height);.     compute_vertical_cost_matrix(energy, cost);.     int seam[height];.     find_minimal_vertical_seam(cost, seam);.     remove_vertical_seam(img, seam);.     delete energy;.     delete cost;.     .   }. }. Thanks.
i_answer: The core issue here is that you cannot create dynamically sized arrays in C. That is, the size of a C array must be determined at compile-time, not run-time. By making the size of the array `height`, which is a variable you have created, the size of the array is determined at run-time. The best way to get around this is to make the size of the seam array the maximum size that it could possibly be. If you end up not using all of the "positions" you created in the seam array, that's completely fine!

subject: seam_carve_width (error: variable length arrays are a C99 feature)
content: When I try to define seam in seam_carve_width and set it to the height of the image, I run into "error: variable length arrays are a C99 feature". How do I define seam to be the height of the image if its size has to be a predetermined constant?
i_answer: There are a few ways of getting around this. You could either use a dynamically allocated array, with the new keyword, or your could just make an array of the max size you would possibly need.

subject: Image_set_pixel and Image_fill - accessing pixels
content: For functions like Image_set_pixel and Image_fill, I'm a little confused with how we can set colors. Is there a Pixel allotted for each pixel in the image, such that if we set RGB values for that pixel, it will change the color? Or do we have to access the red/green/blue_channel members of Image and change those to actually change the color? Sorry if this is a little unclear -- wasn't sure about the best way to word it!
i_answer: Yes, each Pixel represents a pixel in the image. You can set the color of the pixel by going into the red_channel, green_channel, and blue_channel, and changing the value of each for the pixel of the specified row. Hope that makes sense to you!

subject: I see question 778's answer
content: I'm having an issue trying to pass the "Respecting image and matrix interface" test for Image_tests.cpp.  . . I have used functions like Image_width() and Image_height() whenever applicable and I have eliminated all of the incorrect accesses of the structures members, apart from these 3;. Screen_Shot_2023-01-23_at_10.40.19_PM.png. . My issue here, is that there is no way that you can pass the test in question and access red_channel.width to see if it was initialized.. . There are no functions in image.cpp that give you a pointer to a matrix, meaning there is no way to call the Matrix_width() function, meaning there is no way to properly check the width member of any of the color channels. Height as well
i_answer: You shouldn't need to check the height/width of the individual channels in Image_tests.cpp. This is because the testing of matrix functions should be done in Matrix_tests.cpp. In Image_tests.cpp, using Image_height() and Image_width() is sufficient for testing the init functions.

subject: Autograder -o Matrix_tests_respect_interfaces.o
content: I am confused as to what this error is telling me, do I need to create the struct first? Screenshot_2023-01-23_at_10.15.54_PM.png
i_answer: @778 offers some workable strategies around the interface constraint for testing Image. Since Matrix_tests is not part of the definition of Matrix, it cannot directly access any "private" members of Matrix. According to course convention, all the member variables of Matrix and Image are considered private, so you cannot refer to Matrix's member variables outside Matrix.h or Matrix.cpp, and you cannot refer to Image's member variables outside Image.h and Image.cpp. For Matrix_tests, you should use `Matrix_height(mat)` instead of `mat->height` and `Matrix_width(mat)` instead of `mat->width`.

subject: Respecting image and matrix interfaces in student tests
content: When working in Image_tests.cpp, I cannot imagine any possible way in which you can pass this autograder test. The autograder tests fails if it detects any  instance of (*img).red_channel or img->red_channel, but using one of these two methods is the only way I can see to get access to the matrices inside of img. There are not any Image.h functions that give you a reference to one of the images matrices, and this means you also have no hope of finding a solution in one of matrix.cpp's functions because they all take a matrix pointer as parameter. This is an issue, because in Image_tests.cpp to test that the Image_init function works properly you should also test whether or not it initialized the widths and heights of the matrices inside of img. Am I missing something?
i_answer: Well, for the Image_init() width and height issue, you can use the Image_width() and Image_height() to get the width and height. . -- op Im aware of this part my confusion was on how to get access to red_channel.width and red_channel.height. *** og answerer: Ah, I get what you mean now. Though if you test it the printing way I beleive you will catch that kind of error, since if the channels aren't the right size you wont get the right output.. . For the first part, you have Image_get_pixel() which gives you the pixel with the rgb value, so you can access it through that way and test each pixel manually.. . Another way you can do this is create a string with the correct output and run Image_print() into a string, and then compare the values of the two. If you don't know how to do that, check out the test_image_from_and_to_stream test in Image_public_test.cpp. -- I think this will work in a roundabout way, It'll be more work than I think it should be, but it'll doer. *** I did it that way, it's not too much work, you can just change around the test from Image_public_test.cpp to match what you need

subject: Project 2 - find_minimal_vertical_seam: checking the REQUIRES clause
content: How do we get the length of the seam Array to check for "the size of seam is >= Matrix_height(cost)" inside an assert statement? I've tried using a few guides online, but I haven't found any success.Any pointers (no pun intended)?
i_answer: The quick answer is that finding the size of a C array isn't as straight forward as finding the size of a `vector` (just v.size()) and that you aren't required to `assert` things to ensure that a function means the requires clause. It can just be assumed that the parameters are valid in p2.. . The longer answer is that `sizeof` will return the size of a type or variable in *bytes*. So if we know the size of the array and the size of an integer, we can divide them to get the number of integers in an array.. . ```. int length = sizeof(seam) / sizeof(int);  . ```. **EDIT:** Since the seam is passed into `find_minimal_vertical_seam`, it does not encode its total size---it is just a pointer, or a memory address. You can't verify that REQUIRES clause via an assert statement, and nor do you have to.

subject: Inputs for resize.cpp on private tests
content: Currently my resize.cpp checks to make sure the inputs are dog.ppm, crabster.ppm, and horses.ppm files and throws an error if the input is not one of these three. Do the private tests use files other than this. If so, how should we determine what the max width and height should be.
i_answer: Your program should work with any input .ppm file, so you should not restrict it to those 3. You can use the MAX_MATRIX_WIDTH and MAX_MATRIX_HEIGHT const global variables found in Matrix.h.

subject: Project2 Error output
content: Can someone explain to me what is memory leaks error？ Thanks！. .
i_answer: see @698 for info on memory leaks. in this project, it is probably due to using `new` without a `delete` at the end of the function scope. for example:. . ```. image *img = new Image;. Image_init(parameters);. //...do stuff with image.... // end function. ```. the above code would cause a memory leak because we do not use `delete` to deallocate memory space created using `new`.. . to fix this, use the `delete` keyword after you're done using the image:. . ```. image *img = new Image;. Image_init(parameters);. //... do stuff with image.... delete img;. // end function. ```

subject: Image_init(istream version) IStream NOT WORKING :(
content: TMy istream is not working for some reason. . I just typed is >> "hi"; and it is giving me this error.. . What can I do to fix this?.
i_answer: In this function, `is` is your input data file. istream is helpful in this situation because it allows you to take your input (which is in the `istream is` parameter) and read it into other variables that you create. For your situation, I assume that you are trying to write into the istream (similar to how you would `cout << ` something), but in reality it works the other way. For example, if you did:. ```. string x;. is >> x;. ```. This would read the first word of the istream into the variable x.

subject: Image_init (instream function) question
content: I've finished all the other functions in image.cpp other than this one and I am currently stuck.. . I was thinking of using is >> // code here and using maybe some variable to keep track of the number of rows and columns so I can initalize them later after running through the for loops.. . Is that the right way of approaching this problem?. . Other than that, this function will only change the width and heights of the image correct?. .
i_answer: . I was thinking of using is >> // code here and using maybe some variable to keep track of the number of rows and columns so I can initalize them later after running through the for loops.. . Is that the right way of approaching this problem?. . You definitely want to use the >> operator to read in data from the PPM file. You can then insert this data into the necessary matrices. One approach to keeping track of the rows and columns is to use a nested loop. . . . Other than that, this function will only change the width and heights of the image correct?. . This function should also initialize red_channel, green_channel, and blue_channel. . . Follow Up: should we use the 1-D representation of the Matrix struct when implementing this function? . . Or just use Matrix_at()?. . Do not access data outside of Matrix.cpp, use Matrix_at

subject: Requires Clause for Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row and Matrix_min_value_in_row
content: Hello, I had a question about the requires clause for these two functions. In both of them, it states that column_end must be between 0 and Matrix_width(mat) inclusive. I am a bit confused on this though, because if this were the case, that would mean that column_end would go one over the final index of the array (since width is 1 more than the last index of the array since it starts at 0 not 1). When I was debugging these functions I was running into problems since my for loop went to strictly less than column_end because of this requires statement. As a result though, I was missing the final column it was supposed to be checking. I fixed it by making my loop run up to and including column_end, but now am worried this may access out of bounds in certain cases since that value could be outside the array. Is this a mistake in the requires clause or do I just need to think of a way around it without accessing out of bounds?
i_answer: Notice the effects clause in these functions. . . // EFFECTS:  Returns the minimal value in a particular . // region. The region is defined as elements in the . // given row and between column_start (inclusive) and . // column_end (exclusive).. . Since column_end is exclusive, your function should be able to handle an input that is equal to the width.
